{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} This is a list of '''Polish cardinals'''. It includes all ethnic [[Poles]], living and deceased, who were raised to the rank of [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinal]] by [[pope]]s of the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. Cardinals are senior officials of the Church who collectively form the [[College of Cardinals]], a body that elects and advises the supreme pontiff. This list includes cardinals who were born or carried out their pastoral services outside Poland, such as Cardinal [[Kazimierz Świątek]] who was born in Estonia and worked as a bishop in Belarus. People of other ethnic origins who were [[Naturalization|naturalized]] in Poland, such as the 17th-century Hungarian-born Cardinal [[Andrew Bathory|Báthory Endre]], are not included. Three of the Polish cardinals, namely [[Fryderyk Jagiellończyk]], [[Jan Olbracht Waza]] and [[John II Casimir of Poland|Jan Kazimierz Waza]], were of royal blood. The latter was elected king of Poland after he had renounced his cardinalate. [[Pope John Paul II|Karol Wojtyła]] was the only Polish cardinal to be elected pope. As Pope John Paul II, he elevated ten of his compatriots to cardinalate, the largest number of Polish cardinals created by a single pope. Roughly one out of two Polish cardinals was a bishop of one of Poland's historically two most important episcopal sees: [[Gniezno]], the capital city of Poland until 1034, and [[Kraków]], Poland's capital from 1038 to 1596. All bishops of Kraków since 1890, as well as all [[primate (bishop)|primates]] of Poland (an honorific title traditionally bestowed on the archbishop of Gniezno), since 1919 have been created cardinals. Cardinals are sorted in chronological order by date of elevation to cardinalate, indicated in the ''Elevated'' column. Cardinals elevated during the same century are marked by the same color on the bar on the left-hand side of the table. The date of elevation is the date of the [[Papal consistory|consistory]] during which a given person was officially proclaimed cardinal by the pope. In some cases, especially in former times, a cardinal may have received the [[Galero|red hat]] after the consistory or never. Those, whose elevation was intended by a pope, but died before the consistory, as well as [[pseudocardinal]]s elevated by [[antipope]]s, are listed in ''italics''. Two of the cardinals listed here, Jan Olbracht Waza and [[Marian Jaworski]], were elevated ''[[in pectore]]'', which means that their names were kept secret by the pope and revealed only on later consistories. In these cases, the date of elevation is the date of the ''in pectore'' elevation, not the date of the subsequent publication. Cardinals are technically deacons or priests of [[Rome|Roman]] churches known as ''[[Titulus (Roman Catholic)|tituli]]''. Their ranks (cardinal deacon or cardinal priest; there have been no cardinal bishops of Polish origin) and titular churches are indicated in the ''Cardinal title'' column. The "Other titles" column shows other, especially [[Bishop (Catholic Church)|episcopal]], titles held by the given person during his cardinalate. The ''Conclaves'' column lists all [[Papal conclave|conclaves]], that is papal elections, that took place during a person's cardinalate and indicates whether he participated in a given conclave or not. Since [[Ingravescentem aetatem]] in 1970, cardinals who are 80 years or older at the beginning of a conclave are ineligible to participate.Pope Paul VI, ''[http://www.ewtn.com/library/PAPALDOC/P6INGAET.HTM Ingravescentem aetatem]'', 21 November 1970 The ''Ref.'' column provides links to external online references. {{clear}} {|class="wikitable" border="1" style="font-size:90%" |- ! !Name !Born !Elevated !Cardinal title !Other titles !Conclaves !Died !Notes !Ref. !Image |- |style="background:Crimson"| |[[Zbigniew Oleśnicki (cardinal)|Zbigniew Oleśnicki]] |Sienno,
5 December 1389 |{{nowrap|18 December 1439}} by [[Pope Eugene IV]] |Cardinal Priest of S. Prisca |[[List of Roman Catholic Bishops of Kraków|Bishop of Kraków]] |[[Papal conclave, 1447|1447]] – absent |[[Sandomierz]],

They are listed below by date of birth. {|class="wikitable" border="1" |- !Name !Born !Age !Electoral rights expire |- |[[Stanisław Dziwisz]] |27 April 1939 |{{Age nts|1939|04|27}} |27 April 2019 |- |[[Zenon Grocholewski]] |{{nowrap|11 October}} 1939 |{{Age nts|1939|10|11}} |{{nowrap|11 October}} 2019 |- |[[Stanisław Ryłko]] |4 July 1945 |{{Age nts|1945|07|04}} |4 July 2025 |- |[[Kazimierz Nycz]] |1 February 1950 |{{Age nts|1950|02|01}} |1 February 2030 |- |[[Konrad Krajewski]] |25 November 1963 |{{Age nts|1963|11|25}} |25 November 2043 |} == Sources == {{Commons category|Cardinals from Poland}} *{{cite web |last=Miranda |first=Salvador |title=The Cardinals of the Holy Roman Church |publisher=Florida International University Library |date=1998–2008 |url=http://webdept.fiu.edu/~mirandas/cardinals.htm |accessdate=18 October 2008}} *{{cite web |last=Cheney |first=David |title=The Hierarchy of the Catholic Church |date=1996–2007 |url=http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org |accessdate=18 October 2008}} *{{cite web |title=The Catholic Encyclopedia |publisher=Robert Appleton Company |year=1911 |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/ |accessdate=18 October 2008}} [[Category:Lists of cardinals by country|Polish]] [[Category:Polish cardinals| ]] [[Category:Lists of Polish people by occupation|Cardinals]] [[Category:Poland religion-related lists|Cardinals]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Jesus and history]]; added [[Category:Religious perspectives on Jesus]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[File:Codex Boreelianus F+ (09), Mk 1.JPG|thumb|180px|A 9th-century [[Gospel of Mark]], from [[Codex Boreelianus]].]] In [[Biblical criticism]], the '''Messianic Secret''' refers to a motif primarily in the [[Gospel of Mark]] in which Jesus is portrayed as commanding his followers to maintain silence about his Messianic mission. Part of [[William Wrede]]'s theory involved statements in the [[New Testament]] by [[Jesus]] to demons who recognize his divine nature as well as to his followers not to reveal to others that he is the [[Messiah]].[[William Wrede]], [https://archive.org/details/dasmessiasgeheim00wred ''Das Messiasgeheimnis in den Evangelien: Zugleich ein Beitrag zum Verständnis des Markusevangeliums''], (Göttingen: Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, 1901); English edition, William Wrede, ''The Messianic Secret'', trans. The Rev'd James C. G. Grieg (Cambridge: James Clarke & Co., 1971).James L. Blevins. ''The Messianic Secret in Markan Research, 1901–1976''. Washington, D. C.: University Press of America, 1981. {{ISBN|978-0-8191-1606-2}} Wrede suggested that this theme was not historical but was an addition by the author of Mark. Wrede's broad concept of the Messianic Secret also involved the use of parables by Jesus. Wrede's theory had an inherent inter-relationship with the hypothesis of [[Markan priority]], which Wrede eventually abandoned, but some of his followers accepted. The theory was strongly criticized in the first years of the 20th century, then gained acceptance in the 1920s; but eventually began to lose support and by the 1970s it no longer existed as Wrede had proposed it. ==New Testament examples== In the [[New Testament]], Jesus commands silence in many instances.W. R. Telford. ''The New Testament, a Short Introduction'', pp. 139. Oneworld. Oxford. 2002. {{ISBN|978-1-85168-289-8}} An example is [[s:Bible (American Standard)/Mark#8:29|Mark 8:29–30]]: 29 And he asked them, “But who do you say that I am?” Peter said to him in reply, “You are the Messiah.” 30 Then he warned them not to tell anyone about him. Jesus also issues commands of silence after [[Miracles of Jesus|miracles]] and healings, e.g. in [[s:Bible (American Standard)/Mark#1:43|Mark 1:43–45]] in the cleansing of a leper: 43 Then, warning him sternly, he dismissed him at once. 44 Then he said to him, “See that you tell no one anything, but go, show yourself to the priest and offer for your cleansing what Moses prescribed; that will be proof for them.” 45 The man went away and began to publicize the whole matter. He spread the report abroad so that it was impossible for Jesus to enter a town openly. He remained outside in deserted places, and people kept coming to him from everywhere. The concept, as Wrede used it, also included [[Parables of Jesus|parables]] and secrets of the [[Kingdom of God]] as in [[s:Bible (American Standard)/Mark#4:11|Mark 4:11]]: 11 * He answered them, “The mystery of the kingdom of God has been granted to you. But to those outside everything comes in parables, ==Wrede's theory== Wrede proposed that the author of Mark invented the notion of secrecy to reduce the tension between [[Early Christianity|early Christian]] beliefs about Jesus being the Messiah, and the non-Messianic nature of his ministry.''Gospel According to St. Mark'' by Morna Dorothy Hooker 2001 {{ISBN|0-8264-6039-9}} pages 66-69 However, Wrede's notion of secrecy did not simply rely on the commands of Jesus but also involved the "Markan parable theory" of why Jesus spoke in parables. Wrede recognized the inherent inter-relationship of his approach with the hypothesis of [[Markan priority]] – namely that Mark was written first and influenced the other Gospels. However, after re-examining his initial theory, Wrede suggested that his theory would work best if the Markan priority hypothesis turned out to be false and wrote: "it would be 'most highly desirable' if such a gospel as Mark were not the oldest gospel".''Christology and the Synoptic problem'' by Peter M. Head 1997 {{ISBN|0-521-58488-4}} pages 233-235 Yet, the followers of the Messianic Secret hypothesis were later forced to assume Markan priority – an issue that has resulted in various forms of criticism by other scholars. ==Analysis and interpretation== ===Criticism=== Soon after the appearance of the theory in 1901, theologians such as [[William Sanday (theologian)|William Sanday]] and [[Albert Schweitzer]] reacted negatively to it.[[William Sanday (theologian)|William Sanday]], ''The Life of Christ in Recent Research'' (New York: Oxford University Press, 1907).[[Albert Schweitzer]], ''Von Reimarus zu Wrede'' (Tubingen: J. C. B. Mohr, 1906); English edition, Albert Schweitzer, ''The Quest of the Historical Jesus: A Critical Study of its Progress from Reimarus to Wrede'', trans. W. Montgomery (New York: Macmillan, 1948). Initially, scholarship was strictly divided, although suggestions to bridge a gap between the opposing views were made. Wrede's broad concept of the Messianic Secret also involved the use of [[Parables of Jesus|parables]] by Jesus, and in his criticism Albert Schweitzer called it the weakest element of Wrede's approach.''The Christology of Mark's Gospel'' by Jack Dean Kingsbury 1983 {{ISBN|0-8006-2337-1}} pages 2-11 Wrede's theory enjoyed its highest level of acceptance in the 1920s, and support for it began to decline thereafter as criticisms of the theory were provided based on multiple new arguments.''Jesus: an historical and theological investigation'' by Jonathan Knight 2004 {{ISBN|0-8264-6981-7}} pages 139-141 In the 1960s [[Ulrich Luz]] demonstrated that the commands of silence which Jesus gave to healed persons belonged to a different category from those issued to his disciples. By the mid-1970s the Messianic Secret theory no longer existed as Wrede had proposed it. Late in the 20th century, criticism of both the motif and the theory continued from a number of other perspectives, e.g. [[Daniel J. Harrington]], a former professor at the Weston Jesuit School of Theology, argued that even the term "Messianic Secret" is a misnomer, has lumped together multiple issues and some of the Biblical terms used have been confused.''The Gospel of Mark, Volume 2'' by John R. Donahue, Daniel J. Harrington 2002 {{ISBN|0-8146-5965-9}} pages 28-29 [[George Eldon Ladd|G. E. Ladd]] , a former Baptist professor at Fuller Theological Seminary, stated that: "The 'Messanic Secret' is a clever theory, but utterly lacking in evidence".''A theology of the New Testament'' by George Eldon Ladd 1993 {{ISBN|0-8028-0680-5}} pages 178-180 ===Other explanations=== Other explanations regarding the commands of secrecy issued by Jesus have been proposed, e.g. [[Philology|philological]] explanations based on mistranslations. An example is the explanation suggested by the Exegetic School of [[Madrid]] based on the [[Aramaic primacy]] that Jesus never expressed those ideas, and that they were added as a result of mistranslation of what Jesus said.José Miguel García. ''Los orígenes históricos del Cristianismo''. Madrid 2007, 168. However, there is no extant copy of this alleged Aramaic original to support this proposal. The historical explanations generally assume that the Gospel of Mark is historical and that Jesus issued the commands. Based on that assumption, various additional theories have been proposed, e.g. that Jesus issued the commands in order not to become a "celebrity" and be able to move about with ease. The theological explanation was proposed by Wrede: it was not yet the proper time for him to be revealed as such. He knew when he had to go to the court and then be crucified. In Mark 8:30 Jesus, "Then strictly warned them that they should tell no one about Him." Jesus' messianic mission cannot be understood apart from the cross, which the disciples did not yet understand (vs. 31–33 and ch. 9 vs. 30–32). This theological explanation is supported by Matthew's explicit link between Pharisaic conspiracy to "destroy" {{Cite web|url=http://www.esvbible.org/Matthew+12/|title=Matthew 12:14 ESV|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Matthew 12 - ESVBible.org|publisher=Crossway|access-date=October 29, 2016}} Jesus and the latter's command to his followers "not to make him known."{{Cite web|url=http://www.esvbible.org/Matthew+12/|title=Matthew 12:16 ESV|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Matthew 12 - ESVBible.org|publisher=Crossway|access-date=October 29, 2016}} Aware of the plot against him, Jesus "withdrew from there" and continued his healing ministry.{{Cite web|url=http://www.esvbible.org/Matthew+12/|title=Matthew 12:15 ESV|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Matthew 12 - ESVBible.org|publisher=Crossway|access-date=October 29, 2016}} Matthew goes one step ahead and claims that Jesus' conscious decision to fulfil his ministry by avoiding untimely conflict was a fulfilment of [[Isaiah|Isaiah's]] prophecy,{{Cite web|url=http://www.esvbible.org/Isaiah+42/|title=Isaiah 42:1-4 ESV|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Isaiah 42 - ESVBible.org|publisher=Crossway|access-date=October 29, 2016}}
Behold, my [[Servant songs|servant]] whom I have chosen, my beloved with whom my soul is well pleased. ... He will not quarrel or cry aloud, nor will anyone hear his voice in the streets; a bruised reed he will not break, and a smoldering wick he will not quench, until he brings justice to victory; and in his name the Gentiles will hope.{{Cite web|url=http://www.esvbible.org/Matthew+12/|title=Matthew 12:18-21 ESV|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Matthew 12 - ESVBible.org|publisher=Crossway|access-date=October 29, 2016}}
The literary explanation theory has it that Mark made a conscious effort to identify Jesus with [[Odysseus]], a Greek hero with whom Mark's [[gentile]] audience would certainly have been familiar. Odysseus, on his return home, has to disguise his identity to avoid his enemies, and in Mark the messianic secret could serve the same purpose for Jesus. ==See also== * [[Messiah]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} [[Category:Religious perspectives on Jesus]] [[Category:New Testament theology]] [[Category:Christian messianism]] [[Category:Christian terminology]] [[Category:Gospel of Mark]]

The Mount Zion Foundation has its seat at the Institute for Jewish-Christian Research (IJCF) at the University of [[Lucerne]] in [[Switzerland]] and grants every other year on October 28 the '''Mount Zion Award'''. In 1986 the Mount Zion Foundation was created by the German Reverend Wilhelm Salberg (1925–1996), son of a Jewish father and a Christian mother. Every other year, this foundation grants the Mount Zion Award to persons of Jewish, Muslim or Christian faith, who have significantly contributed to the Jewish-Christian [[Interfaith dialog|dialogue]] or to the understanding of the three Abrahamic religions, Judaism, Christianity and Islam, in Israel.
The presidents of the foundation, Prof. Dr. Verena Lenzen, director of the Institute for Jewish-Christian Research at the University of Lucerne, and the abbot of the [[Hagia Maria Sion Abbey|Dormition Abbey]] in [[Jerusalem]] Bernhard Maria Alter OSB, present the Mount Zion Award always at the end of October, in remebrance of the Declaration on the Relation of the Catholic Church with Non-Christian Religions ''[[Nostra aetate]]'' of October 28, 1965.
== Laureates == *1987: Dr. Mahmoud Abassi, Al-Masreq Publishing House, Shefar´am / Israel; Rose-Therese Sant, Sister of Zion, Jerusalem *1989: [[David Grossman]], author, Mevasseret Zion / Israel *1991: Elisheva Hemker, Pastoral Officer, Haifa + Nahariya / Israel *1993: Dr. Kirsten Stoffregen-Pedersen ("Sister Abraham"), Jerusalem *1995: Elias und Heyam Jabbour, social worker, Shefar`Am / Israel; Yeheskel and Dalia Landau, social worker, Ramle + Jerusalem *1997: [[Sumaya Farhat Naser]], lecturer at the University of [[Bir Zeit]]; Yitzhak Frankenthal, director of Neviot Shalom, Jerusalem *1999: [[Shmuel Toledano]], politician, Jerusalem; Ass`ad Araidy, [[Druze]], mayor of Maghar in [[Galilee]] *2001: Kifaya Jadah; {{ill|Reuven Moskovitz|de}}; Emil Shoufany *2003: "Breaking Barriers", Jerusalem/Tel Aviv *2005: Rabbi Dr. [[David Rosen (rabbi)|David Rosen]] *2007: Sr. Monika Düllmann *2009: Dr. Nedal Jayousi, Palestinian House for Professional Solutions, Ramallah; Daniel Rossing, Jerusalem Center for Jewish-Christian Relations *2011: [[Friends of the Earth Middle East]]; Gidon Bromberg (Israeli Director), Munqeth Mehyar (Jordanian Director), Nader Al-Khateeb (Palestinian Director) *2013: Mrs. Yisca Harani, lecturer, researcher and inter-religious activist. And, Mrs. Margratte Karam. *2015: Fr. Dr. David Neuhaus, Patriarchal Vicar for [http://www.catholic.co.il/index.php?lang=en Hebrew speaking Catholics], Coordinator of the [http://abridgetotheholyland.com/palestine/ouer-lady-women-of-valor-pastoral-center-bethelem Pastoral care of migrants]. *2017: [[Amos Oz]], writer, intellectual, professor of literature at Ben-Gurion University in Beersheba
== External links == * [http://www.dormitio.net/engagement/friedensarbeit/zionaward/zionaward2/index.html Mount Zion Award]
[[Category:Christian and Jewish interfaith dialogue]] [[Category:Religion-related awards]]

{{About|the Mundari speaking ethnic group|a list of all ethnic groups using Munda languages|Munda peoples}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox ethnic group | group = Munda people | native_name = | pop = | region1 = {{flag|India}} | pop1 = 2,228,661 | ref1 = <ref name="census">{{Cite web|url=http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011census/PCA/ST.html|title=A-11 Individual Scheduled Tribe Primary Census Abstract Data and its Appendix|publisher=Office of the Registrar General & Census Commissioner, India|website=www.censusindia.gov.in|access-date=2017-11-18}}</ref> | region2 = [[Jharkhand]] | pop2 = 1,229,221 | region3 = [[Odisha]] | pop3 = 584,346 | region4 = [[West Bengal]] | pop4 = 366,386 | region5 = {{flag|Bangladesh}} | pop5 = 5,000 | ref5 = <ref>{{cite web|title=Mundari Language|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/unr|website=Ethnologue|publisher=SIL International|accessdate=20 October 2017}}</ref> | langs = [[Mundari language|Mundari]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Singh|first1=Geetanjali|last2=Kumar|first2=Jyoti|title=Studies on indigenous traditional knowledge of some aquatic and marshy wild edible plants used by the Munda tribe of district Khunti, Jharkhand, India|journal=International Journal of Bioassays|date=2014|volume=3|issue=2|url=http://www.ijbio.com/index.php/ijb/article/view/20|accessdate=22 October 2017|quote=Munda tribe...ethnically they are proto- Austroloids and speak Mundari language}}</ref><ref name="Osada">{{cite book|last1=Osada|first1=Toshiki|editor1-last=Anderson|editor1-first=Gregory|title=The Munda languages|date=19 March 2008|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=0-415-32890-X|chapter=3. Mundari|quote=...the designation Munda is used for the language family. Mundari, on the other hand, refers to an individual language, namely the language of Munda people.}}</ref>{{rp|99}} | rels = {{hlist | Other ([[Sarnaism]])|Christianity | Hinduism ()}}<ref name="Cen2011">{{cite web|title=ST-14 Scheduled Tribe Population By Religious Community|url=http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011census/SCST-Series/ST14.html|website=Census of India|publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs, India|accessdate=15 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="Srivas">{{cite journal|last1=Srivastava|first1=Malini|title=The Sacred Complex of Munda Tribe|journal=Anthropologist|date=2007|volume=9|issue=4|url=http://krepublishers.com/02-Journals/T-Anth/Anth-09-0-000-000-2007-Web/Anth-09-4-000-07-Abst-PDF/Anth-09-4-327-07-417-Srivastava-M/Anth-09-4-327-07-417-Srivastava-M-Tt.pdf|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref>{{rp|327}} | related = {{hlist | [[Ho people|Hos]] |[[Kol people|Kols]] | [[Kharia people|Kharia]] |[[Juang people|Juang]] | [[Santhal people|Santhals]]| | [[Bhumij]] | and other [[Austroasiatic languages|Mon-Khmer people]] }} }} The '''Munda people''' ([[Hindi]]: मुंडा, [[Assamese language|Assamese]]: মুণ্ডা, [[Bengali language|Bengali]]: মুন্ডা) are an [[Adivasi]] ethnic group of [[India]]. They speak the [[Mundari language]], which belongs to the [[Munda languages|Munda subgroup]] of [[Austroasiatic languages]]. The Munda are found in the northern areas of east India concentrated in the states of [[Jharkhand]], [[Odisha]] and [[West Bengal]]. Munda also reside in adjacent areas of [[Bihar]], [[Chhattisgarh]] and [[Arunachal Pradesh]] as well as in portions of [[Bangladesh]]. The group is one of India's largest [[Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes|scheduled tribes]]. Munda people in [[Tripura]] are also known as Mura, and in [[Madhya Pradesh]] they are often called Mudas.<ref>http://tribesindia.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=792&Itemid=104&lang=en</ref>
[[File:Old Munda Men, Dinajpur, 2010 by Biplob Rahman.jpg|thumb|290px|right|Elderly Munda men]]
==History==
The prehistory of the Munda peoples is obscure. Although how they got to the [[Chota Nagpur Plateau]] is disputed, it is agreed upon that the ancestors of speakers of the modern-day [[Munda languages]] migrated westward from the [[Austroasiatic languages|Austroasiatic]] homeland of continental [[Southeast Asia]].
According to [[Ram Sharan Sharma|R.S. Sharma]], a historian of ancient and early medieval India, many Munda, Dravidian and non-Sanskrit terms occur in Vedic texts ascribed to 1500-500 BCE. They indicate ideas, institutions, products and settlements associated with peninsular and non-Vedic India. Similarly, many [[Pali]] and [[Sanskrit]] terms, signifying ideas and institutions developed in the [[Indo-Gangetic Plain]], appear in the earliest [[Tamil language|Tamil]] texts called the [[Sangam literature]], which was created from 300 BCE to 600 CE. The eastern region, inhabited by the [[Munda peoples|Munda]], people made its own contribution. Several terms that signify the use of cotton, navigation, digging, sticks, etc. in the Indo-Aryan languages have been traced back to the [[Munda languages]]. It is held that changes in the phonetics and vocabulary of the Vedic language can be explained by contact with both [[Munda languages|Munda]] and [[Dravidian languages]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=India's Ancient Past|last=Sharma|first=R.S.|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2006|isbn=9780199087860|location=Oxford|pages=}}</ref>
In the late 1800's, the [[British Raj]] and many non-Mundas were grabbing land traditionally occupied by Mundas, forcing the Mundas to work as bonded labourers. Munda freedom fighter [[Birsa Munda]] began the first protest marches calling for remission of forest dues. He worked to unify the [[Adivasi]]s of [[Chota Nagpur Plateau|Chota Nagpur]] resist British rule of India. [[Millenarianism]] in the [[India tribal belt|tribal belt]] started with him, and he is still revered in [[Jharkhand]], with villagers in his home village worshipping him as Birsa Bhagawan.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/jharkhand-amit-shah-launches-scheme-for-villages-of-freedom-fighters-khunti-4848635/|title=Jharkhand: Amit Shah launches scheme for villages of freedom fighters|last=Pandey|first=Prashant|date=2017-09-18|work=The Indian Express|access-date=2017-10-21|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Culture & tradition== The Munda people probably descended from Austroasiatic migrants from Southeast Asia.<ref>Riccio et al. (2011), [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21740156 ''The Austroasiatic Munda population from India and Its enigmatic origin: a HLA diversity study''].</ref> Nomadic hunters in the [[India tribal belt]], they became farmers who were employed in basketwork and weaving. With the listing of the Munda people as Scheduled Tribes (Adivasis), many are employed in various governmental organizations (particularly [[Indian Railways]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=List of Schedule Castes |publisher=Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment, Government of India |year=2011 |url=http://socialjustice.nic.in/aboutdivision1.php |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923060507/http://socialjustice.nic.in/aboutdivision1.php |archivedate=23 September 2014 }}</ref>
[[File:Encyclopedia mundarica (John-Baptist Hoffmann).JPG|thumb|alt=Eight books on a shelf|upright=1.2|Part of [[John-Baptist Hoffmann]]'s 15-volume ''Encyclopaedia Mundarica'']] Munda religion is a blend of [[Sarnaism]] and Christianity, and they are not part of the [[Indian caste system]]. Although the Mundas have preserved much of their pre-Christian culture, they have absorbed a number of Christian traditions. They have many [[folk songs]], [[dance]]s, [[Narrative|tales]] and traditional [[musical instruments]]. Both sexes participate in dances at social events and festivals. The [[naqareh]] is a principal musical instrument.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}}
The Munda people have elaborate rituals to celebrate birth, death, engagement and marriage. The birth of a boy is celebrated as an earner for the family, and the birth of a girl is celebrated as a family caretaker. ''Lota-pani'' is the engagement ceremony. ''Dali Takka'', a monetary gift to paternal guardians, is generally paid before the marriage. Marriage, considered one of the main rituals of life, is a week-long festivity.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}}
An ointment of scented oil and turmeric is applied to the face and body after death. Widow marriage is common. The Munda people are patrilineal, [[Patrilocal residence|patrilocal]] and patriarchal.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=weK7KuCvNiQC|title=Land and People of Indian States and Union Territories: In 36 Volumes. Jharkhand|last=Bhatt|first=Shankarlal C.|date=2006-01-01|publisher=Gyan Publishing House|isbn=9788178353685|language=en}}</ref>
Involved in agriculture, the Munda people celebrate the seasonal festivals of [[Mage Parab]], Phagu, [[Karam (festival)]], [[Baha parab]], [[Sarhul]] and [[Sohrai]]. Some seasonal festivals have coincided with religious festivals, but their original meaning remains.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecoindia.com/tribes/munda.html|title=Mundas, Munda Tribe in Jharkhand India, Occupation of Mundas|website=www.ecoindia.com|access-date=2016-03-26}}</ref>
Munda people of Jharkhand also follow the old age tradition of Patthalgari i.e. stone erection in which the tribal community residing in the village buries a large inverted u shaped dressed headstone on the head side of grave or entrance of village in which is inscribed the family tree of the dead persons.<ref>http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/20515/11/11_chapter%205.pdf</ref> There are some other types of patthalgari also:- *[[Horadiri]] - It is the stone in which family tree is written. *[[Chalpadiri]] or [[Saasandiri]] - It is the stone in remarking boundary of any village and its limits. *[[Magodiri]] - This is the headstone of social criminal who committed polygamy or unsocial marriage. *[[Ziddiri]] - This is the stone placed on over burial of placenta and dried naval part of a newborn. <ref>https://www.antiquity.ac.uk/projgall/mendaly352</ref><ref>https://scroll.in/article/878468/the-constitution-set-in-stone-adivasis-in-jharkhand-are-using-an-old-tradition-as-a-novel-protest</ref>
==Notable Mundas== [[File:Jaipal Singh Munda- File Picture.jpg|thumb|alt=A seated Jaipal Singh, in light suit and hat|Jaipal Singh]] <!-- ONLY ADD A PERSON TO THIS LIST IF THEY ALREADY HAVE A WIKIPEDIA ARTICLE--> * [[Birsa Munda]]: late 19th-century freedom fighter{{cn|date=May 2018}} * [[Anuj Lugun]]: Poet who received the 2011 Bharat Bhushan Agarwal Award<ref>{{cite web|url=https://in.news.yahoo.com/hindi-stalwarts-praise-tribal-poet-000000197.html|title=Hindi stalwarts praise tribal poet|website=in.news.yahoo.com|access-date=2016-03-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112214729/https://in.news.yahoo.com/hindi-stalwarts-praise-tribal-poet-000000197.html|archive-date=12 November 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *[[Lako Bodra]] - Inventor of Varang kshiti script<ref>http://www.avenuemail.in/region/tata-steel-celebrated-international-day-worlds-indigenous-peoples/96675/</ref> * [[Amrit Lugun]]: Ambassador to [[Yemen]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mea.gov.in/press-releases.htm?dtl/22055/Shri%20Amrit%20Lugun%20appointed%20as%20the%20next%20Ambassador%20of%20India%20to%20Republic%20of%20Yemen|title=Sorry for the inconvenience.|publisher=}}</ref> and a [[South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation]] director<ref>{{cite web|url=http://saarc-sdmc.nic.in/saarc_secretariat.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=23 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403005743/http://saarc-sdmc.nic.in/saarc_secretariat.asp |archivedate=3 April 2015 }}</ref>
==Literature and studies== [[Jesuit]] priest John-Baptist Hoffmann (1857–1928) studied the language, customs, religion and life of the Munda people, publishing the first [[Mundari language]] grammar in 1903. With the help of Menas Orea, Hoffmann published the 15-volume ''Encyclopaedia mundarica''. The first edition was published posthumously in 1937, and a third edition was published in 1976. ''The Mundas and Their Country'', by S. C. Roy, was published in 1912. ''Adidharam'' (Hindi:आदि धर्म) by Ram Dayal Munda and Ratan Singh Manki, in Mundari with a [[Hindi]] translation, describes Munda rituals and customs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tribalstuffs.blogspot.in/2011/11/mundari-language-of-munda-tribe.html|title=Mundari: The Language of Munda Tribe|publisher=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Christianity in Jharkhand]] * [[Korku people]] * [[Munda peoples]] * [[Kolarian]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}

"Santhal tribes present in India" like Jharkhand, Odisha, and West Bengal... Belavadi. * Omkar, patil.(2018). "Kola tribes"...

{{lacking overview|date=April 2014}} {{Shintoism}} {{Nihongo|'''Norito'''|祝詞}} are [[Liturgy|liturgical]] texts or ritual incantations in [[Shinto]], usually addressed to a given ''[[kami]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Philippi|first=Donald L.|title=Norito: A Translation of the Ancient Japanese Ritual Prayers|year=1990|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=0691014892|page=vii}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Norito|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/norito|website=Encyclopedia Britannica}}</ref><ref name="EncyclopediaShinto">{{cite web|last1=Motosawa|first1=Masafumi|title=Norito|url=http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=1246|website=Encyclopedia of Shinto|publisher=Kokugakuin University}}</ref>
==Etymology==
There is no single accepted universally accepted theory to explain the meaning of the term.<ref name="Philippi2">Philippi (1990). p. 2.</ref> One theory derives ''norito'' from ''noru'' ([[wikt:宣#Kanji|宣る]], 'to declare'; cf. the verbs ''[[wikt:祈る|inoru]]'' 'to pray' and ''[[wikt:呪う|norou]]'' 'to curse'<ref name="Philippi2" />) - combined with the suffix ''-to''.<ref name="EncyclopediaShinto" /> A variant term, ''notto'', is derived from a combination of ''norito'' with ''koto'', 'word'.<ref name="EncyclopediaShinto" />
There are various known ways of writing the word in [[kanji]]: aside from 祝詞 (currently the standard), 詔戸言, 詔刀言, and 諄辞 are also attested.<ref name="EncyclopediaShinto" />
One recent writer summed up the original meaning of ''norito'' as "a general term meaning [[Kotodama|magic by means of words]]."<ref>Shiraishi, Mitsukuni, cited in Philippi (1990). p. 2.</ref>
==History==
The first written documentation of ''norito'' dates to 712 CE in the ''[[Kojiki]]'' and 720 CE in the ''[[Nihongi]]''.<ref name="EncyclopediaShinto" />
The [[Engishiki]], a compilation of laws and minute regulation presented by the court compiled in 927 CE, preserves twenty-seven representative forms of ''norito''.<ref>Philippi (1990). p. 1.</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Kitagawa|first1=Joseph Mitsuo|title=On Understanding Japanese Religion|date=1987|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-0691102290|page=67|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h1xcc4cGL5cC&pg=PA67}}</ref>
==Reading==
''Norito'' were (and still are) traditionally written in a variety of ''[[man'yōgana]]'' where [[Japanese particles|particles]] and suffixes are written in a smaller script than the main body of the text.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Sinor|editor1-first=Denis|title=American Oriental Society, Middle West Branch, Semi-Centennial Volume: A Collection of Original Essays|date=1969|publisher=Indiana University Press|pages=242-243|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vGEDAAAAMAAJ}}</ref> This style of writing, used in imperial edicts (宣命 ''senmyō'') preserved in the ''[[Shoku Nihongi]]'' and other texts dating from the 8th century ([[Nara period]]), is known as ''senmyōgaki''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Seeley|first1=Christopher|title=A History of Writing in Japan|date=1991|publisher=Brill|isbn=978-9004090811|pages=54-55|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KCZ2ya6cg88C&pg=PA54}}</ref>
==See also== {{wikisourcelang|ja|祓詞}} {{wikisourcelang|ja|大祓詞}} {{wikisourcelang|ja|六月晦大祓祝詞}}
*[[Kotodama]]

revision.text:
[[File:Stezzano Madonna dei campi.jpg|thumb|The sanctuary of the ''Madonna dei Campi'' at Stezzano (2006 photograph)]] '''Our Lady of the Fields''' (Italian: ''Madonna dei Campi''; French: ''Notre Dame des Champs''; Spanish: ''La Virgen del Campo''; also known as '''Our Lady of Prayer''') is a title of [[Mary mother of Jesus]] in [[Roman Catholic]] [[Marian veneration]]. The name is based on a sanctuary in the countryside of [[Stezzano]], near [[Bergamo]], where [[Marian apparition]]s have been recorded since the 13th century.
Veneration of Mary under this name was taken to [[Canada]] by Jesuit [[Xavier Donald Macleod]], who reports a Marian apparition in a village of [[New France]] in 1841.
Mary is venerated under this name by the [[Glenmary Home Missioners]], a Catholic society of priests and brothers that serve the rural United States. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.glenmary.org/site/epage/97280_919.htm|title=Our Lady of the Fields Prayer - Glenmary|website=www.glenmary.org|language=en|access-date=2018-01-09}}</ref>
==References== *Nicholas J. Santoro, ''Mary In Our Life: Atlas of the Names and Titles of Mary, the Mother of Jesus, and Their Place In Marian Devotion'', 2011, p. 490.
==See also== *[[Notre-Dame-des-Champs (Paris Métro)]] *[[Madonna di Campiglio]] *[[Brothers of Our Lady of the Fields]]
==External links== {{commonscat|Madonna dei Campi (Stezzano)}} *http://www.madonnadeicampi.org/
{{coord missing|Italy}}

{{Infobox book | name = Overcoming Life's Disappointments | title_orig = | translator = | image = Overcoming Life's Disappointments.jpg| caption = Overcoming Life's Disappointments | author = [[Harold Kushner]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Theism]]
[[God]]
[[Religion]] | genre = [[Non-fiction]] | publisher = Anchor Books | release_date = 2006 | english_release_date = | media_type = | pages = 192 pp | isbn = 1-4000-3336-5 | oclc= | preceded_by = [[The Lord Is My Shepherd: Healing Wisdom of the Twenty-third Psalm]] | followed_by = [[Practice Random Acts of Kindness: Bring More Peace, Love, And Compassion]] }} '''''Overcoming Life's Disappointments''''' ({{ISBN|1-4000-3336-5}}) is a 2006 book by [[Harold Kushner]], a [[Conservative Judaism|Conservative]] [[rabbi]]. Kushner addresses in the book the question of how to cope when disappointing things happen to you. He uses Biblical examples, such as how Moses coped with being denied entrance to The Promised Land, as well as secular examples, such as how Abraham Lincoln coped with depression. The emphasis is on the common disappointments faced by many throughout life, such as the breakup of a marriage, death of a loved one, loss of a job, or financial reversals. Rabbi Kushner's book was a ''New York Times'' bestseller for many months in the "nonfiction" category. ==Recognition== *''[[New York Times]]'' bestseller, "nonfiction" ==References== {{Empty section|date=June 2011}} ==External links== * [http://fora.tv/fora/showthread.php?t=457 Rabbi Harold Kushner talks and gives stories in relation to his latest book ''Overcoming Life's Disappointments'' (video)] ==See also== [[Category:2006 books]] [[Category:Religious studies books]] {{Judaism-book-stub}}

{{Expand Polish|Polskie Stronnictwo Ludowe – Porozumienie Ludowe|date=August 2017}} {{Politics of Poland}} The '''Polish People's Party–Peasants' Agreement''' ({{lang-pl|Polskie Stronnictwo Ludowe–Porozumienie Ludowe}}, PSL-PL) was a Christian agrarian political party in [[Poland]].<ref>Larry Diamond (1997) ''Consolidating the Third Wave Democracies, Volume 1'', JHU Press, p126</ref>
==History== The party was established in October 1991 by a merger of [[Rural Solidarity]] and Polish People's Party–Solidarity, the latter a splinter group from the former.<ref name=HDP>Piotr Wróbel (2014) ''Historical Dictionary of Poland 1945-1996'', Routledge, p248</ref> In the [[Polish parliamentary election, 1991|parliamentary elections]] later that year it received 5.5% of the vote, winning 28 seats in the [[Sejm]] and five in the [[Senate of Poland|Senate]].<ref name=NS>[[Dieter Nohlen]] & Philip Stöver (2010) ''Elections in Europe: A data handbook'', pp1511–1513 {{ISBN|978-3-8329-5609-7}}</ref> It joined the coalition governments headed by [[Jan Olszewski]] and [[Hanna Suchocka]], with party leader [[Gabriel Janowski]] serving as Minister of Agriculture.<ref name=HDP/>
In spring 1993 the party left the government in protest at a lack of support for agriculture. Due to several splits and internal disagreements, the [[Polish parliamentary election, 1993|September 1993 elections]] saw the party's vote share fall to 2.4%. As it had failed to pass the 5% electoral threshold, it lost all its parliamentary representation. Following the elections the party disintegrated,<ref name=HDP/> although it was part of [[Solidarity Electoral Action]] in the [[Polish parliamentary election, 1997|1997 elections]].<ref>Aleksander Andrzej Szczerbiak (1989) ''The emergence and development of political parties in post-Communist Poland'' University of London</ref> At a party congress on 15 January 1999 it was decided to merge into [[Ruch Społeczny]].
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Polish political parties}}
[[Category:1991 establishments in Poland]] [[Category:1999 disestablishments in Poland]] [[Category:Agrarian parties in Poland]] [[Category:Christian political parties]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Poland]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1999]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1991]]

{{Hinduism}} '''Prayopavesa''' ({{lang-sa|प्रायोपवेशनम्}}, literally ''resolving to die through fasting'')<ref> {{cite book | last=Monier-Williams | first=Monier |title = Monier Williams Sanskrit-English Dictionary| page=708 |url=http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/cgi-bin/monier/serveimg.pl?file=/scans/MWScan/MWScanjpg/mw0708-prApya.jpg|authorlink=Monier Monier-Williams| accessdate=August 21, 2011|year=2008|origyear = 1899|publisher=[[University of Cologne|Universität zu Köln]] | quote=abstaining from food and awaiting in a sitting posture the approach of death}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.orientalia.org/dictionary-Hindu_Religion-definition24034-Prayopavesa.html|title= Prayopavesa |publisher=''Orientalia''}}</ref> is a practice in [[Hinduism]] that denotes the [[Suicide methods#Starvation|suicide by fasting]] of a person, who has no desire or ambition left, and no responsibilities remaining in life.<ref name="bbc">{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/hinduism/hinduethics/euthanasia.shtml|title= Hinduism - Euthanasia and Suicide|date= 2009-08-25|publisher= [[BBC]]}}</ref> It is also allowed in cases of terminal disease or great disability.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Subramuniya| title = The master course, Book 2| publisher = Himalayan Academy Publications| page = 424| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5iQPJA7GBmIC&pg=PA424| isbn = 978-0-945497-98-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.lifebeyonddeath.org/suicide.html|title= Prayopavesa (Ritual Fasting to Death) by Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami }}</ref> A similar practice exists in [[Jainism]], termed [[Santhara]].
== Conditions and rules == Committing Prayopavesa is bound by very strict regulations. Only a person who has no desire or ambition left, and no responsibilities remaining in life is entitled to perform it. The decision to do so must be publicly declared well in advance.<ref name="bbc" /> Ancient lawmakers stipulated the conditions that allow Prayopavesa. They are one's inability to perform normal bodily purification, death appears imminent or the condition is so bad that life's pleasures are nil and the action is done under community regulation.<ref name="Subramuniyaswami">{{Cite book | last = Subramuniyaswami| first = Sivaya| title = Dancing With Siva: Hinduism's Contemporary Catechism| publisher = Himalayan Academy Publications| year = 2003| page = 833| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=EWlHPAkjBKUC&pg=PA833| isbn = 978-0-945497-96-7}}</ref>
== Examples == It was when the king [[Parikshit]] was observing prayopavesa, that the [[Bhagavata Purana]] was narrated to him by the sage [[Śuka]], son of [[Vyasa]].<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Shastri| first1 = Jagdish| last2 = Kunst| first2 = Arnold|title = Ancient Indian Tradition & Mythology;: The Bhāgavata-purāṇa| publisher = Motilal Banarsidass| year = 1979| page = 73,74,75| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=C8YNAAAAIAAJ }}</ref> In 1982, [[Acharya]] [[Vinoba Bhave]] (spiritual successor of Mahatma Gandhi) died by prayopavesa. [[Vinayak Damodar Savarkar]] also apoted for [[Parikshit]]. In November 2001, [[Satguru Sivaya Subramuniyaswami]] subjected himself to prayopavesa. Subramuniyaswami was diagnosed to be suffering from [[Terminal illness|terminal]] intestinal cancer. He later died on the 32nd day of his fast.<ref name="bbc" />
== See also == * [[Right to die]] * [[Euthanasia]] * [[Sokushinbutsu]] * [[Catharism#Consolamentum|Catharist ''endura'']] * [[Sallekhana]] * [[Hunger strike]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
'''General''' * {{cite web |url= http://www.cuhcs.org.uk/sanskaar/east10.pdf|title= Gayatri Mantra President's Welcome |publisher= Cambridge University Hindu Cultural Society}} * {{cite news|url= http://www.tribuneindia.com/2004/20040803/cth1.htm|title= Is suicide a solution to problems? |date= 2004-08-03|publisher=''[[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]]''}} * {{cite news|url= http://www.india-today.com/itoday/20020107/na-culture.shtml|title= Temple in Bloom|date= 2001-12-24|publisher=''[[India Today]]''}} * {{cite news|url= http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking+News/Singapore/Story/STIStory_298208.html|title= No 'blessings'|date= 2008-11-04|publisher=''[[The Straits Times]]''}} * {{Cite book | last = Lorenzen| first = David| title = Who invented Hinduism: essays on religion in History - New perspectives on Indian pasts| publisher = Yoda Press| year = 2006| isbn = 978-81-902272-6-1}}

revision.text:
{{Pie chart |thumb = right |caption = Religion in Mozambique (2007 census<ref name="The World Factbook - Mozambique"/>) |label1 = [[Christianity]] |value1 = 56.1 |color1 = DodgerBlue |label2 = [[Irreligion in Mozambique|No religion]] |value2 = 18.7 |color2 = Black |label3 = [[Islam]] |value3 = 17.9 |color3 = Green |label4 = Other/Unknown |value4 = 7.3 |color4 = Red }} [[File:Sé da Beira.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Beira Cathedral]] [[Image:Mozambique.jpg|thumb|200px|right|A [[Muslim]] worshiper awaits by the door of a Mozambique [[mosque]]]] [[Image:Salamanga Hindu temple.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Hindu temple in [[Salamanga]]]] According to the most recent census conducted by the National Institute of Statistics in 2007, 56.1% of the population of [[Mozambique]] were [[Christian]], 17.9% were [[Muslim]] (mainly [[Sunni]]), 18.7% had no religion, and 7.3% adhered to other beliefs.<ref name="The World Factbook - Mozambique"/> These figures need to be used with caution, especially those for the population that is categorised as having no religion, a significant section of whom is likely to practice traditional animist beliefs.<ref name="ReferenceD">Eric Morier-Genoud, “Renouveau religieux et politique au Mozambique: entre permanence, rupture et historicité”, ''Politique africaine'', n°134, June 2014, pp.155-177</ref>
Religious communities are dispersed throughout the country.<ref name=report>[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2010/148708.htm International Religious Freedom Report 2010: Mozambique]. United States [[Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor]] ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].''</ref> The northern provinces are predominantly Muslim, particularly along the coastal strip, but some areas of the northern interior have a stronger concentration of Protestant or Catholic communities.<ref name=report/> Protestants and Catholics are generally more numerous in the southern and central regions, but Muslim minority populations are also present in these areas.<ref name=report/>
The National Directorate of Religious Affairs in the Ministry of Justice states [[evangelical Christians]] represent the fastest growing religious group in the country.<ref name=report/> Generally religious communities tend to draw their members from across ethnic, political, economic, and racial lines.<ref name=report/>
There are 732 [[religious denominations]] and 144 religious organizations registered with the Department of Religious Affairs of the Ministry of Justice.<ref name=report/> During the reporting period 10 denominations and 20 religious organizations were registered.<ref name=report/> Major Christian religious groups include [[Anglican]], [[Baptist]], [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church), [[Congregational]], [[Christadelphians]], [[Methodist]], [[Church of the Nazarene|Nazarene]], [[Presbyterian]], [[Jehovah's Witnesses]], [[Roman Catholic]], [[Seventh-day Adventist]], and [[Universal Church of the Kingdom of God]], as well as [[evangelicalism|evangelical]], [[Eastern Orthodox Church|apostolic]], and [[Pentecostal]] churches.<ref name=report/> Many small, independent Protestant and Catholic churches that have split from mainstream denominations fuse African traditional beliefs and practices within a Christian framework.<ref name=report/>
The overwhelming majority of Muslims are [[Sunni]] belonging to [[Shafi]] school of [[jurisprudence]] influenced with [[Sufism]], with a tiny [[Shi'a]] minority (a few families) principally of South Asian origin.<ref name=report/> The growing South Asian immigrant population is predominantly [[Sunni]] [[Muslim]] and follows the [[Hanafi school]] of Islamic [[jurisprudence]].<ref name=report/> The three principal Islamic organizations are the Islamic Congress, the Islamic Council, and the [Asian] Muslim Community.<ref name=report/> The Kuwaiti-funded and Sudanese-managed nongovernmental organization (NGO) African Muslim Agency conducted [[humanitarian]] work, as did the Muslim development agency Aga Khan.<ref name=report/>
[[Jewish]], [[Hindu]], and [[Bahá'í Faith]] groups are registered and constitute a very small percentage of the population.<ref name=report/>
The country's leading [[mosques]] and the Catholic Church have tried to eliminate some traditional indigenous practices from their places of worship, instituting practices that reflect a stricter interpretation of sacred texts; however, some Christian and Muslim adherents continue to incorporate traditional practices and rituals, and religious authorities have generally been permissive of such practices.<ref name=report/>
Foreign [[missionary]] groups operate freely in the country.<ref name=report/> Some groups offer religious teaching centers to their local communities, while others provide scholarships for students to study in their respective countries.<ref name=report/>
The Constitution provides for [[freedom of religion]], and the Government generally respects this right in practice.<ref name=report/>
==Survey results==
{| class="wikitable" border="1" style="width: 70%; font-size:90%;" |+ style="font-size:110%;" | Religious affiliation in Mozambique |- ! width="15" |Affiliation ! width="10" |1997 census<ref>[http://www.ine.gov.mz/home_page/censos_dir/recenseamento_geral/ 1997 Census of Mozambique]</ref> ! width="10" |2007 census<ref>[http://www.ine.gov.mz/censo2007 2007 Census of Mozambique]</ref><ref name="The World Factbook - Mozambique"> [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mz.html#People The World Factbook - Mozambique]</ref> ! width="10" |2009 DHS Survey<ref name="DHS 2009">{{cite web|url=https://dhsprogram.com/pubs/pdf/AIS8/AIS8.pdf|title=Inquérito Nacional de Prevalência, Riscos Comportamentais e Informação sobre o HIV e SIDA em Moçambique (INSIDA), 2009|publisher=Ministério da Saúde & Instituto Nacional de Estatística|language=Portuguese|format=PDF|page=32|accessdate=20 April 2018}}</ref> ! width="15" |2010 Pew Forum Estimates<ref name="Pew Christians">{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2011/12/19/table-christian-population-as-percentages-of-total-population-by-country/|title=Table: Christian Population as Percentages of Total Population by Country|publisher=Pew Research Center|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="Pew Muslims">{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2011/01/27/table-muslim-population-by-country/|title=Table: Muslim Poplation by Country|publisher=Pew Research Center|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref> ! width="10" |2015 DHS Survey <ref name="DHS 2015">{{cite web|url=https://dhsprogram.com/pubs/pdf/AIS12/AIS12.pdf|title=Moçambique: Inquérito de Indicadores de Imunização, Malária e HIV/SIDA em Moçambique (IMASIDA), 2015|publisher=Ministério da Saúde & Instituto Nacional de Estatística|language=Portuguese|format=PDF|page=40|accessdate=20 April 2018}}</ref> |- | [[Christianity|Christian]] | 49.1% | 56.1% | 61.3% | 56.1% | 69.4% |- | style="text-align:left; text-indent:30px;"| [[Catholic]] | 23.8% | 28.4% | 32.3% | 28.4% | 30.5% |- | style="text-align:left; text-indent:30px;"| [[Zionist Christian]] | 17.5% | 15.5% | 7.4% | | 10.3% |- | style="text-align:left; text-indent:30px;"| [[Evangelical]] | 7.8%<ref group="note" name="1997Census">In the 1997 census "Evangelical" included "Protestant".</ref> | 10.9% | | | 9.5% <ref group="note" name="2015DHS">In the 2015 DHS Survey "Evangelical" included "Pentecostal".</ref> |- | style="text-align:left; text-indent:30px;"| [[Protestant]] | | | 21.6% | 27.1%<ref group="note" name="2010Pew">The 2010 Pew Estimates included all Protestants.</ref> | 18.4% |- | style="text-align:left; text-indent:30px;"| [[Anglican]] | | 1.3% | | | 0.8% |- | [[Islam|Muslim]] | 17.8% | 17.9% | 19.5% | 22.8% | 19.3% |- | [[Irreligion|None]] | 23.1% | 18.7% | 12.8% | | 9.9% |- | Other/Unknown | 10.0% | 7.3% | 6.4% | | 1.4% |- | colspan="6"| '''Notes''' <references group="note"/> |}
==Anti-Religious Campaign 1979-1982== The ruling party of Mozambique since independence, known as [[Frelimo]], became predominantly [[Marxist]] during the [[Mozambican War of Independence|liberation war]]. After independence, it declared [[state atheism]] and it nationalized all schools and health facilities, until then owned and run in their majority by religious institutions. Faced by resistance, the [[Communist Mozambique|new state]] imprisoned some clerics in 1975 and 1976 and banned all Jehovah's Witnesses to a district in Zambezia in 1977.<ref name="ReferenceA">Eric morier-Genoud, “Of God and Caesar: The Relation between Christian Churches and the State in post-Colonial Mozambique, 1974-1981”, ''Le Fait Missionnaire ''(Lausanne), n°3, September 1996</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://dw.de/as-feridas-abertas-pelo-processo-de-reeducação-em-moçambique/a-16948901|newspaper=[[Deutsche Welle]]|access-date=March 13, 2015|title=As feridas abertas pelo processo de reeducação em Moçambique|trans-title=The wounds opened by the re-education process in Mozambique|language=Portuguese}}</ref>
In response to the changes in the social and religious situation after Mozambique, the Roman Catholic Church vented public criticism. Catholic bishops condemned a godless society and criticized the death penalty and re-education camps. In 1978 it decided to transform into a church of communities, something the state understood as a move towards [[Mozambican Civil War|resistance]] to [[Socialism]], rather than the collaboration stated by some Bishops. The result was an outright attack on all religion on the part of the state.<ref>Serapiao, Luis Benjamim. "The Catholic Church and conflict resolution in Mozambique's post-colonial conflict, 1977-1992." ''Journal of Church and State ''46.2 (2004)</ref>
From early 1979, the regime attempted to discredit the church on the basis of the history of the colonial church, and it began a campaign to close churches, prevent religious activities and restrict the movements of religious staff. Catholic and other religious institutions resisted, more or less openly. By 1980, resistance was often open and bad international criticism was rife, something which convinced Frelimo to change its stance.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Several Protestant groups in Mozambique had strong allegiance to the Frelimo government, potentially because many in the Frelimo leadership (including the late national hero Eduardo Mondlane) had been trained in Protestant schools and the World Council of Churches had supported the Mozambique institute in Dar es Salaam during the war of liberation.<ref>Serapiao, Luis Benjamim. "The Catholic Church and conflict resolution in Mozambique's post-colonial conflict, 1977-1992." ''Journal of Church and State'' 46.2 (2004)</ref> But many non-Catholic churches suffered much nonetheless, not least the Jehovah's Witnesses who were all deported to Zambezia and the Nazarene Church which saw many of its missionaries imprisoned.
Islam suffered probably the most during the Anti-religious campaign, because of the plain misunderstanding or prejudice of the Frelimo leadership. Ministers thought, for example, that raising pigs was a good idea to combat underdevelopment and they genuinely did not understand resistance on the part of Muslims in the north of the country. Some long-lasting trauma was thus created.<ref>Eric Morier-Genoud, “L’Islam au Mozambique après l’indépendance. Histoire d’une montée en puissance”, ''L’Afrique Politique 2002'', Paris: Karthala, 2002, pp. 123-146; Bonate, Liazzat J. K. , “Muslim Religious Leadership in Post-Colonial Mozambique.” South African Historical Journal, No 60 (4), 2008, 637-654.</ref>
Renamo benefitted from Frelimo's anti-religious attack. Some campaigning was done nationally and internationally by the rebel movement on the subject of religion already in 1978, but with little long-lasting impact - only some radical American and English Pentecostal groups openly sided with Renamo. The guerilla stance was indeed eventually ambiguous in relation to religious institutions, and the movement did not hesitate to take religious hostages or kill missionaries, national priests, pastors or nuns.
The anti-religious campaign of Frelimo formally ended in 1982 when the party in power held a meeting with all the main religious institutions. On that occasion, it claimed mistakes had been made and national unity needed to prevail. State control of religious institutions continued after 1982, but the state attack on faith had come to an end.<ref>FRELIMO (1983) ''"Consolidemos aquilo que nos une": reunião da Direcção do Partido e do Estado com os representantes das confissões religiosas 14 a 17 de Dezembro de 1982'', Imprensa Nacional de Moçambique, Maputo</ref>
==See also== *[[Bahá'í Faith in Mozambique]] *[[Hinduism in Mozambique]] *[[Irreligion in Mozambique]] *[[Islam in Mozambique]] *[[Protestantism in Mozambique]] *[[Roman Catholicism in Mozambique]] *[[Christian Council of Mozambique]]
==References== {{reflist}}
