page.title: Section 116 of the Constitution of Australia

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} '''Section 116 of the [[Constitution of Australia]]''' precludes the Commonwealth of Australia (''i.e.'', the federal parliament) from making laws for establishing any religion, imposing any religious observance, or prohibiting the free exercise of any religion. Section 116 also provides that no religious test shall be required as a qualification for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth. The product of a compromise in the pre-[[Federation of Australia|Federation]] constitutional conventions, Section 116 is based on similar provisions in the [[United States Constitution]]. However, Section 116 is more narrowly drafted than its US counterpart, and does not preclude the [[States and territories of Australia|states of Australia]] from making such laws. Section 116 has been interpreted narrowly by the [[High Court of Australia]]: while the definition of "religion" adopted by the court is broad and flexible, the scope of the protection of religions is circumscribed. The result of the court's approach has been that no court has ever ruled a law to be in contravention of Section 116, and the provision has played only a minor role in [[Constitutional history of Australia|Australian constitutional history]]. Among the laws that the High Court has ruled not to be in contravention of Section 116 are laws that provided government funding to religious schools, that authorised the [[Adelaide Company of Jehovah's Witnesses v Commonwealth|dissolution of a branch of the Jehovah's Witnesses]], and that enabled the forcible removal of [[Indigenous Australian]] children from their families. [[Federal Government of Australia|Federal Governments]] have twice proposed the amendment of Section 116, principally to apply its provisions to laws made by the states. On each occasion—in [[Australian referendum, 1944|1944]] and [[Australian referendum, 1988 (Rights and Freedoms)|1988]]—the proposal failed in a referendum. ==Text of the provision and location in the Constitution== Section 116 states:
The Commonwealth shall not make any law for establishing any religion, or for imposing any religious observance, or for prohibiting the free exercise of any religion, and no religious test shall be required as a qualification for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth.{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|coaca430|Constitution|116}} Commonwealth not to legislate in respect of religion
Section 116 has four limbs. The first three limbs prohibit the Commonwealth from making certain laws: laws "for establishing any religion"; laws "for imposing any religious observance"; and laws "for prohibiting the free exercise of any religion". The fourth limb proscribes the imposition of religious tests to qualify for any Commonwealth office or public trust.{{Harvnb|Blackshield & Williams|2010|p=1165}} Only the "establishing religion" and "prohibiting free exercise" limbs have been the subject of cases before the High Court. The section sits in Chapter V of the Constitution, which deals with the states of Australia. However, Section 116 does not apply to the states.{{Harvnb|Clarke, Keyzer & Stellios|2009|p=1207}} Each state has its own constitution, and only Tasmania's has a provision similar to Section 116.{{Harvnb|Blake|2009|p=287}} Commentators attribute the erroneous location of Section 116 to a drafting oversight caused by the weariness of the committee charged with finalising the draft Constitution.{{Harvnb|La Nauze|1972|p=228}} ==Origins== [[File:Hbhiggins.jpg|thumb|left|[[H. B. Higgins]], proponent of Section 116 in the pre-Federation constitutional conventions|alt=A black and white portrait of [[H. B. Higgins]]]] The Constitution was the product of a series of constitutional conventions in the 1890s. The issues of religious freedom and secularism were not prominent in the convention debates, which focused on the economic and legislative powers of the proposed Commonwealth parliament.{{Harvnb|McLeish|1992|p=217}} The first draft of Section 116, approved by the Melbourne Convention of 1891, would have prohibited the states from passing laws prohibiting the free exercise of religion. The Commonwealth was not mentioned because it was assumed that the Commonwealth parliament would have no power to make such laws.{{Harvnb|Quick & Garran|1901|p=951}} At the Melbourne Convention of 1897, Victorian delegate [[H. B. Higgins]] expressed concern about this assumption and moved to expand the provision to cover the Commonwealth as well as the states. The amendment was initially defeated, but Higgins later succeeded in having the eventual version of Section 116 adopted by the convention in a 25–16 vote. Higgins feared opposition to the provision from convention delegates concerned that the provision would impede the states' legislative powers, so the version passed by the convention did not mention the states.{{Harvnb|Williams|2002|pp=35–36}}{{Harvnb|McLeish|1992|p=220}} The proposed inclusion of Section 116 in the Constitution was the subject of some dissent in the 1897 Melbourne Convention and the final convention in 1898. Protestant churches in New South Wales argued that the Constitution should state that divine providence is the "ultimate source of law", while convention delegates [[John Quick (politician)|John Quick]] and [[Patrick Glynn]] moved to have God explicitly recognised in the Constitution.{{Harvnb|McLeish|1992|p=218}} The [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]] campaigned for a strict separation of church and state, being concerned that the Commonwealth might prohibit its members from working on Sundays.{{Harvnb|McLeish|1992|pp=218–219}} Both sides to some extent achieved their objectives: Section 116 was approved by the final convention, while Glynn successfully moved for the symbolic mention of "Almighty God" in the preamble to the British statute that was to contain the Constitution.{{Harvnb|McLeish|1992|pp=218–220}} The Constitution was then approved by popular referendums in each of the six colonies and took effect on 1 January 1901 (the colonies thus became the states of Australia).{{Harvnb|Irving|1999|pp=415–416}} Section 116 reflects two provisions of the [[United States Constitution]]: the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]], which prohibits the making of laws for the establishment of religion and guarantees the free exercise of religion; and [[Article Six of the United States Constitution|Article VI]], Section 3, which [[No religious test clause|prohibits the imposition of religious tests]] for public offices.{{Harvnb|Cumbrae-Stewart|1946|p=207}}{{Harvnb|Bailey|1951|p=327}} Academic Clifford L. Pannam, writing in 1963, called Section 116 a "fairly blatant piece of transcription" of its US counterparts.{{Harvnb|Pannam|1963|p=41}} However, in practice, Section 116 has been interpreted more narrowly than the US provisions.{{Harvnb|Puls|1998|pp=163–164}} ==Judicial consideration== The High Court's consideration of Section 116 has generally been limited to three areas: the definition of "religion"; the meaning of "law for establishing any religion"; and the meaning of "law for prohibiting the free exercise of any religion". The two other elements of the provision—the clauses prohibiting the Commonwealth from imposing of religious observance and from prescribing religious tests for public offices—have not been the subject of any cases before the court.{{Harvnb|Villalta Puig & Tudor|2009|p=61}} The court has never ruled a legislative provision to be in contravention of Section 116.{{Harvnb|Clarke, Keyzer & Stellios|2009|p=1228}} As a result of the court's narrow and literal interpretation of Section 116, the provision has played a minor role in Australian constitutional history.{{Harvnb|Williams|1994|p=90}} ===Meaning of "religion"=== A threshold test considered by courts applying Section 116 is whether a belief seeking constitutional protection is a "religion".{{Harvnb|Clarke, Keyzer & Stellios|2009|p=1209}} The leading authority on the question is the 1983 judgment of the High Court in ''Church of the New Faith v Commissioner for Pay-Roll Tax (Vic)''.{{cite AustLII|HCA|40|1983|litigants=Church of the New Faith v Commissioner for Pay-Roll Tax (Vic) |parallelcite=(1953) 154 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 120 |courtname=auto}}. The court found that [[Scientology]] was a religion, despite some justices commenting that its practices were "impenetrably obscure". In reaching this finding, the court argued that the definition of religion needed to be flexible but should recognise the need to be sceptical of disingenous claims of religious practice. Justices [[Anthony Mason (judge)|Anthony Mason]] and [[Gerard Brennan]] held:
... the criteria of religion [are] twofold: first, belief in a supernatural, Being, Thing or Principle; and second, the acceptance of canons of conduct in order to give effect to that belief.{{cite AustLII|HCA|40|1983|litigants=Church of the New Faith v Commissioner for Pay-Roll Tax (Vic) |parallelcite=(1953) 154 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 120 |courtname=auto}} per Mason and Brennan JJ at para. 17.
Justices [[Ronald Wilson]] and [[William Deane]] were less prescriptive, setting out five "indicia" of a religion: a belief in the supernatural; a belief in ideas relating to "man's nature and place in the universe"; the adherence to particular standards, codes of conduct or practices by those who hold the ideas; the existence of an identifiable group of believers, even if not a formal organisation; and the opinion of the believers that what they believe in constitutes a religion.{{Harvnb|Clarke, Keyzer & Stellios|2009|pp=1209–1210}}{{Harvnb|Puls|1998|p=145}}{{cite AustLII|HCA|40|1983|litigants=Church of the New Faith v Commissioner for Pay-Roll Tax (Vic) |parallelcite=(1953) 154 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 120 |courtname=auto}} per Wilson and Deane JJ at para. 18. ==="Establishing any religion"=== The courts have taken a narrow approach to the interpretation of the prohibition against "establishing any religion", deriving from the 1981 case of ''[[Attorney-General (Vic) (Ex rel Black) v Commonwealth]]'' (the ''DOGS'' case),{{cite AustLII|HCA|2|1981|litigants=[[Attorney-General (Vic); Ex Rel Black v Commonwealth]] ("DOGS case") |parallelcite=(1981) 146 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 559 |date=2 February 1981 |courtname=auto}}. in which the High Court held that Commonwealth funding of religious schools did not contravene Section 116.{{Harvnb|Puls|1998|pp=143–145}} Chief Justice [[Garfield Barwick]] held that a law would only contravene the provision if establishing a religion was its "express and single purpose", while Justice [[Harry Gibbs]] argued that the section only prohibits the establishment of an official state religion. Each justice in the majority contrasted Section 116 with its equivalent in the US Constitution to find that Section 116 is narrower. The court noted that the US Constitution prohibits laws respecting "establishment of religion" generally, whereas the prohibition in Section 116 is against the establishment of "''any'' religion": this meant that Section 116 did not encompass laws that benefit religions generally; it only proscribed laws that established a particular religion.{{Harvnb|Puls|1998|pp=143–144}} The approach of the High Court to the establishment limb of Section 116 thus largely reflects the views expressed by Constitutional scholars [[John Quick (politician)|John Quick]] and [[Robert Garran]] in 1901, that establishment means "the erection and recognition of a State Church, or the concession of special favours, titles, and advantages to one church which are denied to others."{{Harvnb|Puls|1998|p=158}} ==="Prohibiting the free exercise of any religion"=== The protection of the free exercise of religion was also interpreted narrowly in early High Court judgments.{{Harvnb|Clarke, Keyzer & Stellios|2009|pp=1217–1218}} In 1912, the court in ''Krygger v Williams'',{{cite AustLII|HCA|65|1912|litigants=Krygger v Williams |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1912/65.pdf (1912) 15 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 366] |courtname=auto}}. held that a person could not object to compulsory military service on the ground of religious belief. The court considered that Section 116 would only protect religious observance from government interference; it would not permit a person to be excused from a legal obligation merely because the obligation conflicted with his or her religious beliefs. In a 1929 case, Higgins, then a Justice of the High Court, suggested (as ''[[obiter dictum]]'') that a person could lawfully object to [[compulsory voting]] on the grounds of religious belief.{{Harvnb|Clarke, Keyzer & Stellios|2009|p=1218}} However, in 1943, the court continued the narrow approach it took in ''Krygger v Williams'', upholding war-time regulations that caused the [[Adelaide Company of Jehovah's Witnesses v Commonwealth|Adelaide branch of the Jehovah's Witnesses]] to be dissolved and have its property acquired by the Commonwealth government. The government had declared the branch to be an organisation whose activities were "prejudicial to the defence of the Commonwealth": one of the branch's professed beliefs was that the government was an "organ of [[Satan]]". Chief Justice [[John Latham (judge)|John Latham]] held that the Constitution permitted the court to "reconcile religious freedom with ordered government".{{Harvnb|Clarke, Keyzer & Stellios|2009|pp=1218–1223}}{{cite AustLII|HCA|12|1943|litigants=Adelaide Company of Jehovah's Witnesses Incorporated v Commonwealth |link=Adelaide Company of Jehovah's Witnesses v Commonwealth |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1943/12.pdf (1943) 67 {{abbr|CLR|Commonwealth Law Reports}} 116] |courtname=auto}} per Latham CJ at para. 10. In a 1997 case known as the [[Kruger v Commonwealth|''Stolen Generations Case'']],{{cite AustLII|HCA|27|1997|litigants=[[Kruger v Commonwealth]] (Stolen Generations case) |parallelcite=(1997) 190 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 1 |courtname=auto}}. the court upheld an ordinance issued in 1918 that enabled the forcible removal of [[Indigenous Australian]] children from their families. The court reasoned that the purpose of the ordinance was not to prohibit the free exercise of religion even though the ordinance may have had that effect.{{Harvnb|Clarke, Keyzer & Stellios|2009|pp=1223–1224}} Peter Edge, an academic specialising in religion and the law, thus concludes that Section 116 will only "prevent legislation that has a prohibited purpose, rather than a prohibited effect".{{Harvnb|Edge|2006|p=75}} In her judgment, Gaudron J, while finding that the provision 'cannot be construed as impliedly conferring an independent or free-standing right which, if breached, sounds in damages at the suit of the individual whose interests are thereby affected' left open the possibility that it might nonetheless, in limiting Commonwealth legislative power, apply to a provision that has the effect, as opposed merely to the purpose, of limiting free exercise. ==Commentary== When the Constitution took effect in 1901, Quick and Garran argued that Section 116 was redundant as the Commonwealth had not been given the legislative power under [[Section 51 of the Australian Constitution|Section 51]] to establish a religion or prohibit its free exercise.{{Harvnb|Quick & Garran|1901|p=952}} In 1963, Pannam wrote that the provision was regarded "by all as having little practical value". Pannam considered the provision would only become significant if the High Court held that it applied to laws made by governments of the territories. Constitutional scholar [[George Williams (lawyer)|George Williams]], writing in 1994, criticised the court's literal interpretation of the provision and others in the Constitution, saying the court has "transformed the Constitution into a wasteland of civil liberties". Williams argues that as an "express guarantee of personal freedom", the provision should be interpreted broadly and promote "individual liberty over the arbitrary exercise of legislative and executive power". Academics Gonzalo Villalta Puig and Steven Tudor have called for the court to broaden Section 116 by finding in it an implied right to the freedom of thought and conscience. In their view most Australians correctly "believe that the Constitution protects the right to freedom of thought and conscience just like it protects other civil and political freedoms", and that the court should give effect to that belief. They argue there is precedent for the court finding implied constitutional rights, such as the 1992 case of ''[[Australian Capital Television Pty Ltd v Commonwealth]]'',{{cite AustLII|HCA|45|1992|litigants=[[Australian Capital Television Pty Ltd v Commonwealth]] |parallelcite=(1992) 177 [[Commonwealth Law Reports|CLR]] 106 |courtname=auto}}. where the court found that the Constitution guaranteed the freedom of political communication.{{Harvnb|Villalta Puig & Tudor|2009|p=66}} In defence of Section 116 and the High Court's interpretation of it, Joshua Puls argues that the provision is appropriately limited, suggesting that a rigid "wall of separation" between religion and the state is undesirable, and that the stronger Constitutional protection of religion in the United States has become overly politicised. Fellow academics Jennifer Clarke, Patrick Keyzer and James Stellios argue that the court's narrow interpretation of the provision is consistent with the intention of the Constitution's drafters, who never intended for it to be a protection of individual rights,{{Harvnb|Clarke, Keyzer & Stellios|2009|p=1227}} while Kevin Booker and Arthur Glass say the provision has "symbolic value". Booker and Glass defend the court's interpretation of the provision and other Constitutional rights, saying "the High Court can only work with the constitutional provisions before it".{{Harvnb|Booker & Glass|2009|p=172}} ==Referendums== {{See also |Australian referendum, 1944 |Australian referendum, 1988 (Rights and Freedoms)}} Federal governments have twice proposed [[Referendums in Australia|referendums]] to expand the scope of Section 116: in 1944 and in 1988. In 1944, [[John Curtin]]'s [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] government put a package of measures, known as the "Fourteen Powers referendum", to the Australian public. The purpose of the package was mainly to widen the Commonwealth's legislative powers for the purposes of post-war reconstruction. The widening of powers would [[sunset provision|sunset]] after five years. One of the measures in the package was to extend Section 116 so that it prohibited the states, not merely the Commonwealth, from making the laws proscribed by the section. The package's 14 measures—which included diverse matters such as powers to provide family allowances and legislate for "national health"—were bound together in a single question. [[H. V. Evatt]], the Labor [[Attorney-General of Australia|Attorney-General]], argued that [[freedom of religion]] was "fundamental to the whole idea of democracy" and that the suppression of civil rights by dictatorships in Europe demonstrated the need for Australia to have a strong Constitutional guarantee of the freedom.{{Harvnb |Galligan |1995 |p=98}} The conservative [[United Australia Party]], then in opposition and led by [[Robert Menzies]], campaigned against the package.{{Harvnb |Nethercote |2001 |p=172}} [[Arthur Fadden]], leader of the [[National Party of Australia|Country Party]], claimed a "yes" vote would permit the government to implement a "policy of socialisation".{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6UwQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=75QDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7101,5695609&hl=en |title=Country Party's "No" Campaign |date=25 July 1944 |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |accessdate=10 January 2011}} The package was rejected: the national "yes" vote was less than 46 per cent, and there was majority support for the package only in South Australia and Western Australia.{{cite web |url=http://www.aec.gov.au/Elections/referendums/Referendum_Dates_and_Results.htm |title=Referendum Dates and Results 1906 – present |work=[[Australian Electoral Commission]] |accessdate=9 January 2011}} One reason for the rejection was the bundling of multiple controversial proposals into one question: voters could not vote in favour of the measures they supported and against those they opposed, giving them reason to vote against the entire package.{{cite book |last=Bennett |first=Scott |title=Constitutional Referenda in Australia |publisher=Department of the Parliamentary Library, Parliament of Australia |location=Canberra |year=1999 |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/library/pubs/rp/1999-2000/2000rp02.htm#ACCOUNT |accessdate=2 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207163730/http://www.aph.gov.au/library/pubs/rp/1999-2000/2000rp02.htm#ACCOUNT |archivedate=7 February 2012 |df= }} A similar proposal to amend Section 116 was put to the Australian people in a referendum in 1988. The referendum contained four questions, the last of which sought to amend Section 116 and other constitutional "rights and freedoms". Again, the proposal was initiated by a Labor government (under [[Bob Hawke]]); again, the proposal was opposed by the conservative parties; and again, multiple controversial proposals were bound into one question, being "to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion, and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any government." The proposal in respect of Section 116 was to extend its operation to the states,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com.au/newspapers?id=tq9EAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fZYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5910,5678604&dq=referendum+religion+states+constitution+australia&hl=en |title=Political maturity put to the test |last=Hamer |first=Rupert |date=9 August 1988 |work=[[The Age]] |p=13 |accessdate=2 April 2010}} and expand the protection to cover any government act (not just legislation) that established a religion or prohibited its free exercise.{{Harvnb|Puls|1998|p=160}} Some church officials objected to the proposal, fearing that funding of religious schools by the states could become unlawful.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com.au/newspapers?id=U1kpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gZYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3303,3701810&dq=referendum+religion+australia&hl=en |title=Bishops to deal blow on referendum |last=Grattan |first=Michelle |author2=Doogue, Edmund |date=15 August 1988 |work=The Age |accessdate=7 April 2010}}{{cite news |title=Bowen assurance to schools on 'yes' vote |last=Seccombe |first=Mike |date=16 August 1988 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald}} The question failed to pass, being opposed by a majority of voters in each of the states.{{cite book|title=Constitutional change : select sources on constitutional change in Australia 1901–1997 |publisher=House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs |location=Canberra, Australia |year=1997 |pages=113–114 |isbn=0-644-48410-1 |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/House/committee/laca/ConstitutionalChange/part2.pdf |accessdate=2 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050719100831/http://www.aph.gov.au/house/committee/laca/ConstitutionalChange/part2.pdf |archivedate=19 July 2005 |df= }} The 70 to 30 per cent nationwide vote against the proposal was the largest margin by which a proposal to amend the Constitution had ever been defeated at a referendum.{{Harvnb |Williams |2002 |p=252}} Williams attributes the failure of the proposal mainly to the absence of bipartisan support for it, highlighting the "determined and effective" opposition of senior [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]] politician [[Peter Reith]].{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/frozen-continent/2008/03/28/1206207408050.html?page=2 |title=Frozen continent |last=Williams |first=George |date=29 March 2008 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=9 January 2011}} Williams also points to the "notorious reluctance" of Australians to support Constitutional referendums: of the 44 proposals to amend the Constitution, only eight have succeeded.{{Harvnb |Williams |1994 |p=84}} ==References== ===Footnotes=== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ===Cited academic texts=== {{refbegin}} *{{cite journal |last=Bailey |first=K. H. |year=1951 |title=Fifty Years of the Australian Constitution |journal=The Australian Law Journal |volume=25 |issue=5 |pages=314–343 |issn=0004-9611 |ref=CITEREFBailey1951}} *{{cite book |last=Blackshield |first=Tony |author2=Williams, George |title=Blackshield and Williams Australian Constitutional Law and Theory: Commentary and Materials |publisher=The Federation Press |location=Annandale, NSW |year=2010 |edition=5th |isbn=978-1-86287-773-3 |ref=CITEREFBlackshield & Williams2010}} *{{cite journal |last=Blake |first=Garth |year=2009 |title=God, Caesar and human rights |journal=Australian Bar Review |volume=31 |pages=279–307 |issn=0814-8589 |ref=CITEREFBlake2009}} *{{cite book |last1=Booker |first1=Kevin |last2=Glass |first2=Arthur |editor1-first=H.P. |editor1-last=Lee |editor2-first=Peter |editor2-last=Gerangelos |title=Constitutional Advancement in a Frozen Continent: essays in honour of George Winterton |year=2009 |publisher=Federation Press |location=Annandale, NSW |isbn=978-1-86287-761-0 |chapter=Express Rights |ref=CITEREFBooker & Glass2009}} *{{cite book |last=Clarke |first=Jennifer |author2=Keyzer, Patrick |author3=Stellios, James |title=Hanks' Australian Constitutional Law: Materials and Commentary |publisher=LexisNexis Butterworths |location=Chatswood, NSW |year=2009 |edition=8th |isbn=978-0-409-32440-2 |ref=CITEREFClarke, Keyzer & Stellios2009}} *{{cite journal |last=Cumbrae-Stewart |first=F. D. |year=1946 |title=Section 116 of the Constitution |journal=The Australian Law Journal |volume=20 |issue=6 |pages=207–212 |issn=0004-9611 |ref=CITEREFCumbrae-Stewart1946}} *{{cite book |last=Edge |first=Peter W. |title=Religion and Law: An Introduction |publisher=Ashgate Publishing |location=Aldershot, England |year=2006 |isbn=0-7546-3048-X |ref=CITEREFEdge2006}} *{{cite book |last=Galligan |first=Brian |title=A Federal Republic: Australia's Constitutional System of Government |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Melbourne |year=1995 |isbn=0-521-37354-9 |ref=CITEREFGalligan1995}} *{{cite book |last=Irving |first=Helen |title=The Centenary Companion to Australian Federation |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Melbourne |year=1999 |isbn=0-521-57314-9 |ref=CITEREFIrving1999}} *{{cite book |last=La Nauze |first=J. A. |title=The Making of the Australian Constitution |publisher=Melbourne University Press |location=Carlton, Victoria |year=1972 |isbn=0-522-84016-7 |ref=CITEREFLa Nauze1972}} *{{cite web |last=McLeish |first=Stephen |year=1992 |title=Making Sense of Religion and the Constitution: A Fresh Start for Section 116 |url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/MonashULawRw/1992/10.html |ref=CITEREFMcLeish1992}} (1992) 16(2) [[Monash University Law Review]] 207. *{{cite book |last=Nethercote |first=J. R. |title=Liberalism and the Australian Federation |publisher=Federation Press |location=Annandale, NSW |year=2001 |isbn=1-86287-402-6 |ref=CITEREFNethercote2001}} *{{cite journal |last=Pannam |first=Clifford L. |year=1963 |title=Travelling Section 116 with a U.S. Road Map |journal=[[Melbourne University Law Review]] |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=41–90 |issn=0025-8938 |ref=CITEREFPannam1963}} *{{cite journal |last=Puls |first=Joshua |year=1998 |title=The Wall of Separation: Section 116, the First Amendment and Constitutional religious guarantees |journal=Federal Law Review |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=83–114 |issn=0067-205X |ref=CITEREFPuls1998}} *{{cite book |last=Quick |first=John |author2=Garran, Robert |title=The Annotated Constitution of the Australian Commonwealth |publisher=Legal Books |location=Sydney |origyear=1901 |year=1995 |isbn=1-86316-071-X |ref=CITEREFQuick & Garran1901}} *{{cite journal |last=Villalta Puig |first=Gonzalo |author2=Tudor, Steven |year=2009 |title=To the advancement of thy glory? A constitutional and policy critique of parliamentary prayers |journal=Public Law Review |volume=20 |issue=1 |pages=56–78 |issn=1034-3024 |ref=CITEREFVillalta Puig & Tudor2009}} *{{cite journal |last=Williams |first=George |year=1994 |title=Civil Liberties and the Constitution – A Question of Interpretation |journal=Public Law Review |volume=5 |issue=2 |pages=82–103 |issn=1034-3024 |ref=CITEREFWilliams1994}} *{{cite book |last=Williams |first=George |title=Human Rights under the Australian Constitution |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=South Melbourne |year=2002 |isbn=0-19-554111-1 |ref=CITEREFWilliams2002}} {{refend}} {{Constitution of Australia}} {{featured article}} [[Category:Australian constitutional law]] [[Category:Law about religion in Australia]] [[Category:Freedom of religion]] [[Category:Christianity and law in the 19th century]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox newspaper |name = Shanghai Jewish Chronicle |foundation = May 3, 1939 |language = [[German language |German]] |type = daily newspaper
[[weekly newspaper]] (later) |publishing_country = China |headquarters = [[Shanghai]] |ceased publication = 1948 }} The '''''Shanghai Jewish Chronicle''''' ({{zh|t=上海猶太紀事報|s=上海犹太纪事报|p=Shànghǎi Yóutài Jìshìbào}}"[https://books.google.com/books?isbn=7501161623 《上海犹太纪事报》研究]." [[Google Books]]. Retrieved on May 20, 2013.) was a [[Jewish newspaper]] operating in [[Shanghai]], [[China]]. It was a [[German language]] newspaper that was originally published daily and later published weekly.Goldstein, [https://books.google.com/books?id=V4SmEW0WXCwC&pg=PA160&dq=%22Shanghai+Jewish+Chronicle%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ya6QUIbzLozc8wTonoG4Bg&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Shanghai%20Jewish%20Chronicle%22&f=false 160]. The paper opened on May 3, 1939. The German language newspaper business was increasing in Shanghai due to an influx of Jewish refugees from Europe. Ossi Lewin, J. Kastan, and Horwitz served as the editors.Walravens, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=0F6U82kZXjsC&pg=PA93&dq=%22was+headed+by+Herbert+Mueller%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=X6CQUMG8N46C8QT7xYCIDw&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22was%20headed%20by%20Herbert%20Mueller%22&f=false 93] The newspaper stories included international news and often referred to interests held by Jewish people. It targeted "Jews of the Far East and especially those of the German speaking community." It also discussed emigration problems. Each issue had eight to sixteen pages. Advertising made up about one third of each issue.Walravens, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=0F6U82kZXjsC&pg=PA93&dq=%22was+headed+by+Herbert+Mueller%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=X6CQUMG8N46C8QT7xYCIDw&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22was%20headed%20by%20Herbert%20Mueller%22&f=false 93]-[https://books.google.com/books?id=qubgAAAAMAAJ&q=%22it+comprised+from+six+to+eight+pages%22&dq=%22it+comprised+from+six+to+eight+pages%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=NciQUNDLDMKsywH7voGQCg&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA 94]. After the Japanese took over China, the ''Chronicle'' cooperated with the Japanese administration.Walravens, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=0F6U82kZXjsC&pg=PA95&dq=%22Shanghai+Herald%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-AeYUKi8F6Sa0QGKm4GQAQ&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Shanghai%20Herald%22&f=false 95]. It was the only Jewish newspaper in Shanghai to exist after [[World War II]].Eber, Irene. [https://books.google.com/books?id=oqs0mA9KoycC&pg=PA15&dq=%22sHANGHAI+Jewish+Chronicle%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eaGQULzdL4a29gTDmYDYDw&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22sHANGHAI%20Jewish%20Chronicle%22&f=false 15]. (Introduction) In 1945 it was renamed '''''Shanghai Echo'''''. In 1948 publication ended. == See also== {{Portal|Shanghai|Judaism|Journalism}} * ''[[Der Ostasiatische Lloyd]]'' * ''[[Deutsche Shanghai Zeitung]]'' * ''[[Shen Bao]]'' * ''[[North China Daily News]]'' * ''[[Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury]]'' * ''[[Tsingtauer Neueste Nachrichten]]'' ==References== * Eber, Irene (editor and translator). ''Voices from Shanghai: Jewish Exiles in Wartime China''. [[University of Chicago Press]], October 1, 2008. {{ISBN|0226181669}}, 9780226181660. * Goldstein, Jonathan. ''The Jews of China: Historical and Comparative Perspectives''. [[M.E. Sharpe]], 1999. {{ISBN|0765601036}}, 9780765601032. * Walravens, Hartmut. "German Influence on the Press in China." - In: ''Newspapers in International Librarianship: Papers Presented by the Newspaper Section at IFLA General Conferences''. [[Walter de Gruyter]], January 1, 2003. {{ISBN|3110962799}}, 9783110962796. **[http://ifla.queenslibrary.org/IV/ifla62/62-walh.htm Also available at] ([https://www.webcitation.org/6BorMkdPv Archive]) the website of the [[Queens Library]] - This version does not include the footnotes visible in the Walter de Gruyter version **Also available in Walravens, Hartmut and Edmund King. ''Newspapers in international librarianship: papers presented by the newspapers section at IFLA General Conferences''. [[K.G. Saur]], 2003. {{ISBN|3598218370}}, 9783598218378. ==Notes== ==External links== *{{LBI Collection Links|pid=2339153|title=''Shanghai Jewish Chronicle''|partner=Leo Baeck Institute, New York |callNumber=B1041 | type=Digitized Library Periodical}} *{{LBI Collection Links|pid=2339155|title=''Shanghai Echo''|partner=Leo Baeck Institute, New York |callNumber=B1076 | type=Digitized Library Periodical}} ==Further reading== * Rao, Lihua (S: 饶立华, T: 饒立華, P: ''Ráo Lìhuá''). "[https://books.google.com/books?isbn=7501161623 《上海犹太纪事报》研究]." ("Study of the ''Shanghai Jewish Chronicle''") [[Xinhua Publishing House]] (S: 新华出版社, T: 新華出版社, P: ''Xīn Huá Chūbǎnshè''), 2003. {{ISBN|7501161623}}, 9787501161621. {{Judaism in Shanghai}} {{German-language newspapers outside of German-speaking countries}} [[Category:German-language newspapers published in China]] [[Category:Jewish newspapers]] [[Category:1939 establishments in China]] [[Category:Publications established in 1939]] [[Category:Publications disestablished in 1948]] [[Category:Defunct newspapers of China]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in Shanghai]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Shanghai]]

'''Shuly Rubin Schwartz''' is the Irving Lehrman Research Associate Professor of American Jewish History and Walter and Sarah Schlesinger Dean of Graduate and Undergraduate Studies at The [[Jewish Theological Seminary of America]] (JTS).
Schwartz is a graduate of [[Barnard College]] and the [[Jewish Theological Seminary of America]].<ref>http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/author/schwartz-shuly</ref> She wrote her Ph.D. dissertation at JTS under the direction of [[Ismar Schorsch]].
Her first published book was ''The Emergence of Jewish Scholarship in America: The Publication of the "[[Jewish Encyclopedia]]"''. Her second book, ''The Rabbi's Wife: The Rebbetzin in American Jewish Life'', was awarded a 2006 [[National Jewish Book Award]].

[[Image:Fayum_Portrait_of_a_Boy_(detail).jpg|right|thumb|200px|A '''Totenpass''' in the form of an inscribed metal leaf was sometimes rolled up and inserted into a necklace capsule, as shown in this 2nd-century [[Fayum mummy portraits|funerary portrait from Egypt]].]] [[File:Orphic Gold Tablet (Hipponion-Museo Archeologico Statale Capialbi, Vibo Valentia).jpg|thumb|Gold ''lamella'' from [[Hipponion]], unrolled]] [[Image:Orphic Gold Tablet (Thessaly-The Getty Villa, Malibu).jpg|thumb|left|4th century BC gold orphic tablet from the Getty Museum, Los Angeles]]
'''''Totenpass''''' (plural ''Totenpässe'') is a [[German language|German]] term sometimes used for [[epigraphy|inscribed]] tablets or metal leaves found in burials primarily of those presumed to be initiates into [[Orphism (religion)|Orphic]], [[Dionysus|Dionysiac]], and some ancient [[Ancient Egyptian religion|Egyptian]] and [[ancient Semitic religion|Semitic religions]]. The term may be understood in English as a "[[passport]] for the dead".<ref>Roy Kotansky, "Incantations and Prayers for Salvation on Inscribed Greek Amulets", in ''Magika Hiera: Ancient Greek Magic and Religion,'' edited by Christopher A. Faraone and [[Dirk Obbink]] (Oxford University Press, 1991), p.{{nbsp}}116.</ref> The so-called Orphic gold tablets are perhaps the best-known example.
''Totenpässe'' are placed on or near the body as a phylactery, or rolled and inserted into a capsule often worn around the neck as an [[amulet]]. The [[epigraphy|inscription]] instructs the initiate on how to navigate the [[afterlife]], including directions for avoiding hazards in the landscape of the dead and formulaic responses to the [[Greek underworld|underworld]] judges.
==Examples== [[J. Paul Getty Museum|The Getty Museum]] owns an outstanding example of a 4th-century BC Orphic prayer sheet from [[Thessaly]], a gold-leaf rectangle measuring about {{convert|26|by|38|mm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref>As of September 17, 2008, [[J. Paul Getty Museum|The Getty Villa Malibu]] had this Orphic ''lamella'' on exhibition; information about the piece [http://www.getty.edu/art/gettyguide/artObjectDetails?artobj=8289 online.]</ref> The burial site of a woman also in Thessaly and dating to the late 4th{{nbsp}}century BC yielded a pair of ''Totenpässe'' in the form of ''lamellae'' ([[Latin]], "thin metal sheets", singular ''lamella''). Although the term "[[metal leaf|leaf]]" to describe metal foil is a modern metaphorical usage,<ref>Daniel Ogden, ''Greek and Roman Necromancy'' (Princeton University Press, 2001), p. 188.</ref> these ''lamellae'' were in this case cut in the shape of [[leaf shape|cordate leaves]] probably meant to represent [[ivy]]; most ''Totenpässe'' of this type are rectangular. The [[Greek alphabet|Greek lettering]] is not inscribed in regular lines as it is on the rectangular tablets, but rambles to fit the shape. The leaves are paper-thin and small, one measuring {{convert|40|by|31|mm|in|abbr=on}} and the other {{convert|35|by|30|mm|in|abbr=on}}. They had been arranged symmetrically on the woman's chest, with her lips sealed by a gold ''[[danake]]'', or "[[Charon's obol]]", the coin that pays the ferryman of the dead for passage; this particular coin depicted the head of a [[Gorgon]]. Also placed in the tomb was a [[Greek terracotta figurines|terracotta figurine]] of a [[maenad]], one of the ecstatic women in the retinue of [[Dionysus]].<ref>K. Tasntsanoglou and George M. Parássoglou, "Two Gold Lamellae from Thessaly", ''Hellenica'' 38 (1987), pp.{{nbsp}}3–5.</ref>
Although the meandering and fragile text poses difficulties, the inscriptions appear to speak of the unity of life and death and of [[reincarnation|rebirth]], possibly in divine form. The deceased is supposed to stand before [[Persephone]], Queen of the Dead, and assert "I have been released by [[cult of Dionysus|Bacchios]] himself."<ref>K. Tasntsanoglou and George M. Parássoglou, "Two Gold Lamellae from Thessaly", ''Hellenica'' 38 (1987) 3–16, with photographic plates and line drawings.</ref>
==Interpretation== [[Günther Zuntz]] made the most complete survey of gold tablets discovered up to 1971 (at [[Thurii]], [[Crete]], and elsewhere), categorizing them into three groups that have become the [[Typology (archaeology)|typological]] standard. Zuntz presented [[Transcription (linguistics)|transcribed]] text coupled with a reconstruction, and interpreted their religious foundation as [[Pythagoreanism|Pythagorean]] rather than [[Orphism (religion)|Orphic]].<ref>Günther Zuntz, "The Gold Leaves", in ''Persephone: Three Essays on Religion and Thought in Magna Graecia'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1971); review by [[Joseph Fontenrose]], ''Classical Philology'' 69 (1974) 60–63.</ref> [[Philology|Philologist]] [[Richard Janko]] proposed that Group{{nbsp}}B from Zuntz's collection derived from a single archetype, for which he offered a hypothetical [[ancient Greek|Greek]] text and the following English translation while attempting, he emphasized, not to rely on preconceptions about underlying [[theology]]:<ref>On the problematic relation between [[grave goods]] and [[eschatology]], see Ian Morris, ''Death-ritual and Social Structure in Classical Antiquity'' (Cambridge University Press, 1992) [https://books.google.com/books?id=oMGiB3RV__EC&pg=PA18&dq=%22Orphic%3B+Pythagoreans+or+Dionysiacs%22+intitle:Death-ritual+intitle:and+intitle:Social+intitle:Structure+intitle:in+intitle:Classical+intitle:Antiquity&lr=&as_brr=0&sig=ACfU3U2YVbbkEbNvEcgJILFifGbvpl-rCg pp. 17–18.]</ref>
[[Image:Mnemosyne (color) Rossetti.jpg|left|thumb|150px|''[[Mnemosyne]]'' (1881), a [[pre-Raphaelite]] interpretation of the goddess '''Memory''' by [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]]]] {{quote|You will find on the right in [[Hades]]' halls a spring, and by it stands a ghostly [[cypress]]-tree, where the dead souls descending wash away their lives. Do not even draw nigh this spring. Further on you will find chill water flowing from the pool of [[Mnemosyne|Memory]]: over this stand guardians. They will ask you with keen mind what is your quest in the gloom of deadly Hades. They will ask you for what reason you have come. Tell them the whole truth straight out. Say: 'I am the son of Earth and starry Heaven, but of Heaven is my birth: this you know yourselves. I am parched with thirst and perishing: give me quickly chill water flowing from the pool of Memory.' Assuredly the kings of the underworld take pity on you, and will themselves give you water from the spring divine; then you, when you have drunk, traverse the holy path which other initiates and [[cult of Dionysus|bacchants]] tread in glory. After that you will rule amongst the other heroes.<ref>Richard Janko, "Forgetfulness in the Golden Tablets of Memory," ''Classical Quarterly'' 34 (1984) 89–100, especially p. 99.</ref>}}
The most widely available source that discusses the Orphic gold tablets is the classic (if superseded in some aspects) ''Orpheus and Greek Religion'' by [[W. K. C. Guthrie]].<ref>[[W.K.C. Guthrie]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=-C6wNyrxUO8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=intitle:orpheus+intitle:and+intitle:Greek+intitle:Religion+inauthor:guthrie&lr=&as_brr=0&sig=ACfU3U2RFT3DjQZr0_A0indp_cF4oA-vyg Orpheus and Greek Religion]: A Study of the Orphic Movement'' (New York: Norton, 1966, revised edition), pp. 171–182.</ref> Since the 1990s, the usefulness of the term "Orphic" has been questioned by scholars, as has the unity of religious belief underlying the gold tablets.<ref>Radcliffe G. Edmonds, III, ''Myths of the Underworld Journey: Plato, Aristophanes, and the 'Orphic' Gold Tablets'' (Cambridge University Press, 2004), limited preview [https://books.google.com/books?id=I_YkMvUVoyYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=intitle:Myths+intitle:of+intitle:the+intitle:Underworld+intitle:Journey&lr=&as_brr=0&sig=ACfU3U0VxDa-owmk3oSyuaaBc1muKGs9og here.]</ref> More recently the association of the tablets with Orphism has been defended.<ref>Bernabé, Alberto, and Ana Isabel Jiménez San Cristóbal. ''Instructions for the Netherworld: The Orphic Gold Tablets''. Boston: Brill, 2008: pp.{{nbsp}}204—205.</ref>
''Totenpässe'' have also been found in tombs from [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] dating from the 2nd{{nbsp}}century BC and later. These tiny gold sheets employ a formulaic consolation that appears regularly on funerary [[stele]]s in the area: {{lang|grc|θάρσει}}, (here the name of the deceased is inserted), {{lang|grc|οὐδεὶς ἀθάνατος}} ("Take courage, [name], no one is immortal). In one instance, the inscribed tablet was shaped like a funerary headband, with holes to bind it around the forehead.<ref>Roy Kotansky, "Incantations and Prayers for Salvation on Inscribed Greek Amulets: The Magic ''Lamellae''," in ''Magika Hiera'' (Oxford University Press, 1991), p.{{nbsp}}116; David R. Jordan, review of ''Greek Magical Amulets'' by Kotansky (Opladen, 1994), ''Journal of Hellenic Studies'' 116 (1996), pp.{{nbsp}}233–234.</ref>

"Some Thoughts about the 'New' Gold Tablet from Pherai." ''Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik'' 166 (2008): 53–58. * Comparetti, Domenico, and Cecil Smith. "The [[Petelia Gold Tablet]]." ''The Journal of Hellenic Studies'' 3 (1882): 111–18. * Dickie, M.W. "The Dionysiac mysteries in Pella." ''Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik'' 109 (1995) 81–86. * Edmonds, Radcliffe. ''Myths of the Underworld Journey: Plato, Aristophanes, and the 'Orphic' Gold Tablets''. New York: Cambridge University Press, 2004. * Ferrari, Franco, and Lucia Prauscello. "Demeter Chthonia and the Mountain Mother in a New Gold Tablet from Magoula Mati." ''Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik'' 162 (2007): 193–202. Print. * Freh, J. "Una nuova laminella 'orfica'." ''Eirene'' 30 (1994) 183–184. * Graf, Fritz, and Sarah Iles Johnston. ''Ritual Texts for the Afterlife: Orpheus and the Bacchic Gold Tablets''. New York: Routledge, 2007. * Marcovich, M. "The Gold Leaf from Hipponion." ''Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik'' 23 (1976) 221–224. * [[Reinhold Merkelbach|Merkelbach, Reinhold]]. "Ein neues 'orphisches' Goldblaiittchen." ''Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik'' 25 (1977) 276. * Merkelbach, Reinhold. "Zwei neue orphisch-dionysische Totenpässe." ''Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik'' 76 (1989) 15–16. * Merkelbach, Reinhold. "Die goldenen Totenpässe: ägyptisch, orphisch, bakchisch." ''Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik'' 128 (1999) 1–13. (A collection of examples providing the Greek texts with German translation, also line drawings of Egyptian examples.) * [[Günther Zuntz|Zuntz, Günther]]. revision.comment: They receive their knowledge from "vegetales", the Spanish for plants, not from "vegetables".
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=April 2012}} '''Vegetalismo''' is a term used to refer to a practice of ''[[mestizo]]'' [[shamanic|shamanism]] in the [[Peruvian Amazon]] in which the [[Shamanism|shamans]] — known as ''vegetalistas'' — are said to gain their knowledge and power to cure from the ''vegetales'', or plants of the region. Many believe to receive their knowledge from ingesting the [[hallucinogenic]], [[emetic]] brew [[ayahuasca]].<ref name="luna">[https://www.scribd.com/doc/26541421/Vegetalismo-Shamanism-Among-the-Mestizo-Population-of-the-Peruvian-Amazon Luis Eduardo Luna, ''Vegetalismo shamanism among the Mestizo population of the Peruvian Amazon'']. Scribd.com (1986-06-05). Retrieved on 2012-05-01.</ref><ref name="curelist">''[http://thecurelist.com/vegetalismo/ Vegetalismo]''</ref>
==Terminology== The term ''vegetalismo'' is used to distinguish ''vegetalistas'' from other such healers as ''[[oracionista]]s'' ([[prayer]] healers) and [[espiritismo|espiritistas]] (spiritist healers).<ref name="luna"/> The term is used by followers of [[Brazilian people|Brazilian]] [[new religious movement]]s to refer to both indigenous and mestizo [[ayahuasca]] shamanism in contrast to their practices.<ref>{{cite book|last=Beyer|first=Stephan|title=Singing to the Plants: A Guide to Mestizo Shamanism in the Upper Amazon|year=2009|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|location=Albuquerque|isbn=978-0-8263-4730-5|page=197}}</ref> However, among mestizos in the [[Peruvian Amazon]], the term ''vegetalismo'' is used to distinguish ''[[mestizo]]'' [[shamanism]] from the traditional shamanism practiced by indigenous peoples.<ref name="Beyer">{{cite book|last=Beyer|first=Stephan|title=Singing to the Plants: A Guide to Mestizo Shamanism in the Upper Amazon|year=2009|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|location=Albuquerque|isbn=978-0-8263-4730-5|pages=196–197}}</ref> Related religious movements include the more formal [[União do Vegetal]] and [[Santo Daime]].
==Structure of vegetalismo== The ''vegetalismo'' practice combines deep [[Catholic]] elements with the [[animism|animistic]] religious beliefs common to [[indigenous peoples in Brazil|indigenous]] tribes throughout the region. Though many [[vegetalista]]s declare themselves to be Catholics, they receive their knowledge and power to heal from their special relationship with the [[spirit]]s of the [[Amazon rainforest]].<ref name="luna"/> ''Vegetalistas'' maintain relationships with two types of spirits: the spirits of the healing plants, often appearing in human form, and protective spirits, often appearing as powerful animals, birds, or humans.<ref name="Beyer-nopage">{{cite book|last=Beyer|first=Stephan|title=Singing to the Plants: A Guide to Mestizo Shamanism in the Upper Amazon|year=2009|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|location=Albuquerque|isbn=978-0-8263-4730-5}}</ref> There are other spirit-beings (non-human entities) that exist in the [[visionary]] world that can assist the [[shaman]]; beings that come from other [[planet]]s and [[galaxy|galaxies]], beings that come from [[Infinity|infinite]] [[labyrinth]]s of [[crystal]] rooms, and beings who live in the deep [[rainforest]] and beneath the dark waters.<ref name="Beyer-nopage"/> In contrast to [[indigenous peoples|indigenous]] [[shamanism]] in the [[upper Amazon]], which is based within a [[rural]] environment and whose focus is to maintain or restore social balance, [[mestizo]] [[shamanism]] is based within an [[urban area|urban]] environment and is focused on individual [[healing]]. Many of these mestizo shamans have ''consultarios'' ([[clinics]]), where they provide consultations and healing ceremonies for patients, as well as other services such as massages and general, simple healing sessions, which usually involve the shaman sucking out the sickness from the patient's body, protecting the body with [[shacapa]] and [[tobacco]] [[smoke]], and then prescribing an herbal remedy to help the patient in their recovery from the sickness.<ref name="Beyer-nopage" />
==Initiation== Although ''vegetalismo'' is strongly influenced by indigenous Amazonian cosmology, and to become a ''vegetalista'' one must abide by prescriptions that conform closely to those found among Indian tribes of the upper [[Amazon Basin|Amazon]], ''vegetalistas'' do not associate themselves with any specific tribe, therefore there is no community to support the initiation and recognize that the individual has become a ''vegetalista''.<ref name="luna"/> One becomes a ''vegetalista'' out of personal choice or vocation, and their shamanic powers become recognized gradually as they build up their reputation in the community in which they live.<ref name="luna"/><ref name="Beyer-nopage"/>
;La Dieta In order to ''dominar'', or ''master'' the plants, one must first prove to the plants that he or she is worthy of their trust.<ref name="Beyer"/> They must show the spirits that they are strong and faithful individuals, and in order to do this they must spend generally a minimum of six months in isolation, living deep in the ''monte'' (the [[wilderness]]) in order to take on the odor of the jungle and take in the gifts of the spirits, while following ''la dieta'', the restricted [[diet (nutrition)|diet]] in order to become a very powerful shaman.<ref name="luna"/><ref name="Beyer"/> La dieta is key to forming a relationship with the plants, for the plants will not reveal themselves, their uses, and their [[icaro]]s (sacred songs) to those not following the restricted diet.<ref name="luna"/><ref name="Beyer"/> While a [[wikt:neophyte|neophyte]] is undertaking ''la dieta'', he or she must abstain from [[sugar]], [[salt]], and [[sex]], and often [[oil]] and [[fat]] as well. Generally, human beings smell bad to the spirits, so one must go on this long diet in order to purify oneself from this bad odor. One must practice abstinence while on la dieta in order to eliminate the smell of human sex, for to the spirits this smell is vile and repulsive.<ref name="Beyer"/> However, one must do more than the restricted diet in order to learn the plants, one must also ingest the plant, stay loyal to the plant while taking it into his or her body and allowing it to teach from within.<ref name="Beyer"/> Once the neophyte has undergone la dieta and has won the love of the plants, the spirits of the plants will appear to the neophyte either in visions or dreams. It is then that the plants begin to teach the neophyte their magical healing and protective songs, or ''[[icaro]]s''.
==Gifts of the Spirits== ;Icaros An [[icaro]] is the [[Magic (paranormal)|magic]] [[chant]] or [[melody]] that the [[novice]] receives from the plant spirits after he or she has been purified by the restricted diet.<ref name="luna"/> The word "icaro" may come from the [[Quechua languages|Quechua]] verb ''ikaray'', blow smoke for healing, or it may come from the [[Shipibo]] term ''ikarra'', [[shaman]] song.<ref name="Beyer"/> For indigenous tribes throughout the Amazon, songs are a key component in a healing ritual<ref>{{cite book|last=Langdon|first=Jean Matteson|title=Portals of Power: Shamanism in South America|year=1992|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|location=Albuquerque|pages=1–21}}</ref>
;La Flema Once a neophyte's [[initiation]] is near completion, either the spirits or a senior shaman will give him or her a magic [[phlegm]], a magical saliva-like substance which is also called ''[[yachay]]'', ''llausa'', or ''la flema''.<ref name="luna"/> This substance is known to be the materialization of the shaman's ''fuerza'', or power, and it stored within the shaman's body, usually in the chest or stomach.<ref>{{cite book|title=In darkness and secrecy: the anthropology of assault sorcery and witchcraft in Amazonia|editor=Neil L. Whitehead|editor2= Robin Wright|author=Strathern & Stewart|chapter=Afterword: Substances, Powers, Cosmos, and History|year=2004|publisher=Duke University Press|location=Durham, NC|isbn=9780822333456|pages=314–320}}</ref> This phlegm grows as a result of smoking ''mapacho'' and drinking [[ayahuasca]].<ref name="Beyer"/> Both healers and sorcerers store ''virotes'' (magic darts) in ''la flema'', and within the sorcerer's phlegm one may also find creatures such as toads, scorpions, snakes and insects.<ref name="Beyer"/> A rarefied form of this phlegm, known as ''mariri'', is what makes it possible for the shaman to extract harmful magical darts or a sickness from the patient's body while protecting the shaman from the sorcery and sickness that he/she sucks out.<ref name="Beyer"/> The ''mariri'' is said to be air-like and its power often comes out in the act of ''blowing'', which can both cure and kill depending on its use.<ref name="Beyer"/>
;''Virotes'' The term ''virote'', originally the Spanish name for a very strong arrow, is a term used in ''vegetalismo'' to refer to the magical darts that the shamans and sorcerers store in their phlegm.<ref name="luna"/> Poet César Calvo describes a ''virote'' as a "very small poisoned dart, capable of abandoning and resuming its material shape in order to transverse any distance; any time; any wall, shield, or protection; to nail itself in enemy flesh and to reach the target selected by the sorcerer who gave it form and then animated that form, endowing it with destiny and transcendence."<ref name="Beyer"/> Depending on the culture and various circumstances, these [[pathogenic]] [[projectile]]s can be materialized as a number of different things, including the thorns of spiny palm trees, insects, tiny stones, stingray stings, snake fangs, scorpions, toads, monkey hair, among other menacing things.<ref name="Beyer"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Luna & Amaringo|title=Ayahuasca Visions: The Religious Iconography of a Peruvian Shaman|year=1993|publisher=North Atlantic Books|location=Berkely|isbn=978-1556430640}}[http://ayahuasca.taystes-os.net]</ref> In the practice of shamanism among indigenous groups like the [[Shuar people|Shuar]], these ''virotes'' are often referred to as ''[[tsentsak]]''.
;Magic Stones Magic stones, ''piedras encantadas'', are an important tool in the practice of ''vegetalismo''. The appearance of the stone varies, some have a striking appearance which indicates that they are ''encantada'', for example the stone may be shaped like a person or animal, have an unusual color, or just be rare.<ref name="luna & Amaringo">{{cite book|last=Luna & Amaringo|title=Ayahuasca Visions: The Religious Iconography of a Peruvian Shaman|year=1993|publisher=North Atlantic Books|location=Berkely|isbn=978-1556430640|page=84}}</ref> [[Crystal]]s are particularly prized as ''piedras encantadas'', as they are thought to be of a [[Astronomical object|celestial]] origin.<ref name="Beyer"/> These magical stones are used to help those patients who appear to be victims of [[Magic (paranormal)|sorcery]], the [[shaman]] will place the stone on the body where the [[Magic (paranormal)|sorcery]] has struck and the [[Magic (paranormal)|magic]] stone will stick there for several hours, sucking out the dart, [[phlegm]], [[scorpion]], or whatever harm has been inflicted there by the [[Magician (paranormal)|sorcerer]].<ref name="Beyer"/> In order to master the use of these enchanted stones, the shaman must drink them while following ''la dieta'', just as he does the plants. Before the shaman drinks the water, the stone is left in water for a day, and the shaman blows tobacco smoke over it while telling the stone what it is he wants to know.<ref name="Beyer"/> It is only after this that the spirit of the stone will appear to the shaman in a dream.<ref name="Beyer"/>
==Ayahuasca== {{Main|Ayahuasca}} The ayahuasca ceremony is a widespread practice among ''vegetalistas'', one that has gained a lot of attention in recent years due to the success of the industry of ''ayahuasca tourism'', in which people from all over the world travel to places such as [[Peru]] to partake in an [[ayahuasca]] session led by a ''vegetalismo'' shaman.<ref name="Beyer"/> These sessions vary greatly depending on the vegetalista conducting the ceremony, and there are significant differences between an ayahuasca session held in an urban setting and one held in a rural setting.<ref name="luna"/> In urban settings a shaman will usually hold one of these sessions several times a week, and they usually draw crowds of about twenty people or more, many of whom don't know each other.<ref name="luna"/> In rural settings the groups are much smaller, usually less than ten people, and the people involved often know each other or have kindred ties.<ref name="luna"/> Generally in the urban setting the shaman will meet and speak briefly to everyone in attendance for the ceremony, gathering information on their illnesses and what it is their seeking to find from ingesting ''ayahuasca''. Some people attend these ceremonies regularly as a [[purge]], to cleanse themselves.<ref name="Beyer"/>
==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Curandero]] * [[Icaro]] * [[Mestizo]] * [[Shamanism]] * [[Tsentsak]] * [[Tsunki]] * [[Yachay]] }}
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Mestizo]] [[Category:Shamanism of the Americas]] [[Category:Peruvian culture]] [[Category:Traditional medicine]]
