revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = World Religion Day |type = international |image = |imagesize = |caption = |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = Bahá'ís, interfaith and multi-faith organizations{{Harvnb|Buck|2011|pp=936–938}} |litcolor = |longtype = International, cultural |significance = Celebration of the oneness of religion and its role in human society |week_ordinal = third |weekday = Sunday |month = January |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |celebrations = |observances = |firsttime = December 8, 1949 |relatedto = }} '''World Religion Day''' is an observance initiated in 1950 by the National [[Spiritual Assembly]] of the [[Bahá'í Faith in the United States|Bahá'ís of the United States]], celebrated worldwide on the third Sunday in January each year. Though initiated in the United States, World Religion Day has come to be celebrated internationally. Described as a "[[Bahá'í]]-inspired idea that has taken on a life of its own",{{cite book|title=Religions of the World: A Comprehensive Encyclopedia of Beliefs and Practices|date=September 21, 2010|editor1=J. Gordon Melton|editor2=Martin Baumann|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781598842043|pages=3138–3139|edition=2nd |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=v2yiyLLOj88C&pg=PA3138}} the origins of World Religion Day lie in the Bahá'í principles of the [[Bahá'í Faith and the unity of religion|oneness of religion]] and of [[Progressive revelation (Bahá'í)|progressive revelation]], which describe religion as evolving continuously throughout the history of humanity.{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Progressive revelation |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 1-85168-184-1 |pages= 276–277}}{{cite web|last1=Rameshfar|first1=Saphira|title=January 17, 2016 – World Religion Day: Celebrating Our Unity|url=http://www.theinterfaithobserver.org/journal-articles/2016/1/9/january-17-2016-world-religion-day-celebrating-our-unity.html|website=The Interfaith Observer|accessdate=June 28, 2017}} The purpose of World Religion Day is to highlight the ideas that the spiritual principles underlying the world's religions are harmonious, and that religions play a significant role in unifying humanity. ==Purpose== Initially a Bahá'í observance, World Religion Day was inspired by the Bahá'í principles of the [[Bahá'í Faith and the unity of religion|oneness of religion]] and of [[Progressive revelation (Bahá'í)|progressive revelation]], which describe religion as evolving continuously throughout the history of humanity.{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Progressive revelation |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn= 1-85168-184-1 |pages= 276–277}}{{cite web|last1=Rameshfar|first1=Saphira|title=January 17, 2016 – World Religion Day: Celebrating Our Unity|url=http://www.theinterfaithobserver.org/journal-articles/2016/1/9/january-17-2016-world-religion-day-celebrating-our-unity.html|website=The Interfaith Observer|accessdate=June 28, 2017}} It promotes these principles by highlighting the ideas that the spiritual principles underlying the world's religions are harmonious, and that religions play a significant role in unifying humanity. As a means of clarifying the nature and purpose of World Religion Day, the [[Universal House of Justice]], the elected council that serves as the head of the Bahá'í Faith noted in a 1968 message that, rather than providing a "platform for all religions and their emergent [[Ecumenism|ecumenical]] ideas," the observance serves as "a celebration of the need for and the coming of a world religion for mankind, the [[Bahá'í Faith]] itself."{{cite book |last= The Universal House of Justice |first= |editor1-last= Hornby |editor1-first= Helen |date= 1988 |title= Lights of Guidance (second part): A Bahá'í Reference File |url= http://bahai-library.com/hornby_lights_guidance_2.html | chapter= 1710. World Religion Day, Purpose of |chapter-url= http://bahai-library.com/hornby_lights_guidance_2.html&chapter=4#n1710 |location= Wilmette, Illinois |publisher= Bahá'í Publishing Trust |page= |isbn= 978-8185091464 |author-link= Universal House of Justice }} In April 2002, the Universal House of Justice published a letter, "To the World’s Religious Leaders", in which it stated:
...interfaith discourse, if it is to contribute meaningfully to healing the ills that afflict a desperate humanity, must now address honestly ... the implications of the over-arching truth ... that God is one and that, beyond all diversity of cultural expression and human interpretation, religion is likewise one.{{Harvnb|Buck|2011|pp=937}}
World Religion Day has been described as a "[[Bahá'í]]-inspired idea that has taken on a life of its own", because its observance is no longer confined to the Bahá'í community, where it originally took shape. Although observances of World Religion Day are still sponsored and supported by Bahá'í communities worldwide, Baha'i institutions such as the Universal House of Justice or the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States no longer play active roles in the promotion of events, apart from reporting on them. Instead, an increasing number of observances are independently organized by interfaith or multi-faith coalitions. ==History== The earliest observation entitled "World Peace Through World Religion" was in [[Portland, Maine]] at the [[Eastland Park Hotel]] in October 1947 with a talk by [[Firuz Kazemzadeh]].{{cite news | title =Baha'i community to sponsor address | newspaper =Portland Sunday Telegram And Sunday Press Herald | location =Portland, Maine | page =42 | date =October 19, 1947 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/305472/world_religion_day_observed_with_with/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} In 1949 observances in various communities in the United States made the local newspapers in December called "World Religion Day". * {{cite news | title =Baha'i group | newspaper =The Sun and the Erie County Independent | location =Hamburg, New York | page =2 | date =December 8, 1949 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1749515/bahai_observance_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =World Religion Day proclaimed by Baha'i Faith | newspaper =The Eagle | location =Bryan, Texas | page =2 | date =December 10, 1949 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1749533/bahai_observance_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Baha'i sets Religion Day | newspaper =Long Beach Independent | location =Long Beach, California | page =6 | date =December 17, 1949 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1749544/bahai_observance_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} It was standardized across the United States by the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States in December 1949 to be held January 15.{{cite news | title =Meeting the Crisis; Tell the story; World Religion Day | newspaper =Bahá'í News | page =4 | date =December 1949 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=190 | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} It also began to be observed internationally starting as early as in [[Bahá'í Faith in Australia|Australia]] in 1950 in two cities * {{cite news | title =Baha'i Faith – World Religion Day | newspaper =The Southern Mail | location =Bowral, New South Wales | page =3 | date =January 6, 1950 | url =http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article119219202 | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =World Religion Day observance | newspaper =News | location =Adelaide, South Australia | page =15 | date =January 11, 1950 | url =http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article130794657 | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} and [[Bahá'í Faith in Bolivia|Bolivia]] in 1951.{{cite news | title = Latin American News |newspaper = Bahá'í News |date=March 1951 |number = 241 | page = 7 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=03&page=401}} By 1958 Bahá'ís had gathered notices of events in a number of countries—sometimes attracting hundreds of people and sometimes overlapping with race amity priorities.{{cite news | title =The Oneness of religion is proclaimed internationally with many public observances of World Religion Day | newspaper =Bahá'í News | pages =12–14 | date =March 1958 | url = http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=723 | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} In [[Bahá'í Faith in Laos|Laos]], for example, meetings were noted in 1958,{{cite news | title = Four Faiths Join in Observance of World Reliqion Day in Laos | newspaper = Bahá'í News |date=April 1958 | issue = 326 | page = 11 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=742}} 1959,{{cite magazine | title = Newspaper and Radio Publicity, Visual Aids Assist in Proclaiming World Religion Day Observances on Theme of The Oneness of Religion; The audience at the special World Religion Day Program in Vientiane... |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1959 | issue = 337 | page = 9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=04&page=945}} and 1960, among many countries activities.{{cite book |editor = Rabbani, R. |year = 1992 |title = The Ministry of the Custodians 1957–1963 |publisher = Bahá'í World Centre |isbn = 0-85398-350-X |page = 221 |url = http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians}}{{cite magazine | title = The Oneness of Religion Proclaimed to Millions on World Religion Day|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1960 | issue = 349 | pages = 2–4 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=48}} In [[Bahá'í Faith in the Netherlands|the Netherlands]] in 1962 it was noted in several cities.{{cite magazine | title = First-Time Observances Held by Three Netherlands Communities |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1962 |pages=4–5 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=418 | issue = 373}} ===More pronounced awareness=== The observance has grown in some scale of recognition beginning in the 1950s. It was noted on various [[AM radio]] stations in the 1950s and 1960s: * [[KNBR|(formerly) KVSM]] (1951, San Francisco Bay Area){{cite news | title =Baha'i to have two programs | newspaper =The Times | location =San Mateo, California | page =14 | date =January 19, 1951 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1750118/bahai_observance_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015}} * [[1947 in radio#Stations|(formerly) KCNA]] (1951, Tucson area){{cite news | title =Expect ten at Baha'i convention | newspaper =Tucson Daily Citizen | location =Tucson, Arizona | page =21 | date =January 24, 1951 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1753915/bahais_attend_state_convention_and/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * [[KFAR]] (1951,{{cite news | last =Malloy | first =Fran | title =Baha'i World Religion Day set Jan 21 | newspaper =Fairbanks Daily News-Miner | location =Fairbanks, Alaska | page =1 | date =January 16, 1951 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1750037/bahai_observance_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} 1960,{{cite news | title =Baha'is to observe World Religion Day | newspaper =Fairbanks Daily News-Miner | location =Fairbanks, Alaska | page =5 | date =January 16, 1960 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1756069/bahais_observe_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} and 1962,{{cite news | title =Baha'is religion day is observed | newspaper =Fairbanks Daily News-Miner | location =Fairbanks, Alaska | page =5 | date =January 20, 1962 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1756864/bahais_observe_world_religion_day_with/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} Fairbanks, Alaska) * [[KSFN|(formerly) KTIM]] (1954, San Francisco Bay Area),{{cite news | title =Baha'i's present radio program | newspaper =Daily Independent Journal | location =San Rafael, California | page =10 | date =January 16, 1954 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1754294/bahais_observe_world_religion_day_with/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * [[WIOU (AM)]] (1955, Kokomo, Indiana){{cite news | title =Baha'i lecturer is speaker here for World Religion Day | newspaper =The Kokomo Tribune | location =Kokomo, Indiana | page =9 | date =January 17, 1955 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1754590/bahais_observe_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * [[WGVA]] (1956, Geneva, New York){{cite news | title =Broadcast set | newspaper =The Geneva Times | location =Geneva, New York | page =5 | date =January 14, 1956 | url =http://www.fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2011/Geneva%20NY%20Daily%20Times/Geneva%20NY%20Daily%20Times%201956%20Jan-Mar%201956%20%20Grayscale/Geneva%20NY%20Daily%20Times%201956%20Jan-Mar%201956%20%20Grayscale%20-%200156.pdf | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * [[KVNA (AM)]] (1957, Flagstaff, Arizona){{cite news | title =Baha'is observe World Religion Day | newspaper =Arizona Daily Sun | location =Flagstaff, Arizona | page =9 | date =January 18, 1957 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1764301/bahais_observe_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} Various noted speakers have given talks in the 1950s to the 1970s: * [[O. Z. Whitehead]], actor and writer {{cite news | title =Baha'i spiritual group to hear talk by actor | newspaper =Buffalo Courier-Express | location = | page =3 | date =January 16, 1954 | url =http://www.fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2021/Buffalo%20NY%20Courier%20Express/Buffalo%20NY%20Courier%20Express%201954/Buffalo%20NY%20Courier%20Express%201954%20-%200598.pdf | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * [[Dwight W. Allen]], professor of education and reformer{{cite news | title =Baha'i speaker | newspaper =Daily Independent Journal | location =San Rafael, California | page =21 | date =January 12, 1961 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1756415/bahais_observe_world_religion_day_with/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * [[Stanwood Cobb]], educator and reformer{{cite news | title =Baha'is to celebrate | newspaper =The New York Age | location =New York, New York | page =11 | date =January 3, 1953 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1754182/world_religion_day_program_with_talk_by/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }}{{cite news | title =Two local women planning to attend religious meeting | newspaper =The Circleville Herald | location =Circleville, Ohio | page =8 | date =January 14, 1955 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1754422/bahais_observe_world_religion_day_with/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * [[Hilda Yen]], diplomat and aviator{{cite news | title =Baha'i program here tomorrow | newspaper =The Bridgeport Post | location =Bridgeport, Connecticut | page =2 | date =January 19, 1957 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1755170/bahais_observe_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * [[Robert B. Powers]], police chief and writer{{cite news | title = Baha'i World Day | newspaper =Tucson Daily Citizen | location =Tucson, Arizona | page =8 | date =January 15, 1972 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1768342/bahais_observe_world_religion_day_with/ | accessdate =February 12, 2015 }} * [[William Sears (Bahá'í)|William Sears]], television and radio personality{{cite news | title =Baha'i Faith leader sets visit to Pee Dee | newspaper =Florence Morning News | location =Florence, South Carolina | page =5 | date =January 20, 1973 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1768459/hand_of_the_cause_bill_sears_at_louis/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} A number of locales have seen Mayoral proclamations in the United States and Canada in the 1960s and 1970s: * 1966 – Reno Nevada{{cite news | title =Religion Day observance set | newspaper =Nevada State Journal | location =Reno, Nevada | page =19 | date =January 11, 1966 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1759076/bahais_observe_world_religion_day_with/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} and Portsmouth, New Hampshire{{cite news | title =Proclamation | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =20 | date =January 15, 1966 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1759222/mayor_proclaims_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * 1967 – Arcadia, California{{cite news | title =Religion Day highlights Baha'i goal | newspaper =Arcadia Tribune | location =Arcadia, California | page =28 | date =January 5, 1967 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1767609/bahais_observe_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * 1969 – Carbondale, Illinois{{cite news | title =Baha'i Faith will observe | newspaper =Religion Day Southern Illinoisan | location =Carbondale, Illinois | page =5 | date =January 10, 1969 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1767815/world_religion_day_proclamation_by/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * 1973 – Hamburg, New York{{cite news | title =World Religion Day | newspaper =The Photo News | location =Hamburg, New York | page =12 | date =January 17, 1973 | url =http://www.fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2011/Hamberg%20NY%20Photo%20News/Hamberg%20NY%20Photo%20News%201971-1973/Hamberg%20NY%20Photo%20News%201971-1973%20-%201236.pdf | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * 1974{{cite news | title =World Religion Day to be observed | newspaper =The Brandon Sun | location =Brandon, Manitoba, Canada | page =5 | date =January 19, 1974 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1767609/bahais_observe_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} and 1975{{cite news | title =Proclamation for World Religion Day | newspaper =The Brandon Sun | location =Brandon, Manitoba, Canada | page =18 | date =January 18, 1975 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1771365/world_religion_day_proclamation_by_a/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} – Brandon, Manitoba * 1977 – Hamburg, New York,{{cite news | title =World Religion Day | newspaper =The Hamburg Sun | location =Hamburg, New York | page =5 | date =January 13, 1977 | url =http://www.fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2023/Hamburg%20NY%20Sun/Hamburg%20NY%20Sun%201977%20%20Grayscale/Hamburg%20NY%20Sun%201977%20%20Grayscale%20-%200027.pdf | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} In 1968 the proclamation was issued by [[Warren E. Hearnes]], [[Governor of Missouri]].{{cite news | title =Religion day being observed | newspaper =The Sunday News and Tribune | location =Jefferson City, Missouri | page =8 | date =January 21, 1968 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1767789/governor_warren_hearnes_proclaims_world/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} ===Stamps=== In 1985 [[Sri Lanka]] issued the first World Religion Day [[postage stamp]]. This was followed by a stamp issued by the [[Republic of the Congo]] in 2007. The Congo stamp showed a globe with the symbols of 11 religions surrounding it, and the text (in French) read, "God is the source of all religions."{{Harvnb|Buck|2011|pp=937–938}}[[One Country]]. ''[http://www.onecountry.org/story/congo-republic-issues-stamp-world-religion-day Congo Republic issues stamp for World Religion Day]''. Volume 18, Issue 4. January–March 2007.[http://bahai-library.com/stamps/BahaiStamps.htm Bahá'í Library: Bahá'í Stamps] ===Modern observance=== There is a long tradition of hosting panels and symposia with representatives of many religions at World Religion Day observances. * {{cite news | title =World Religion Day program | newspaper =The Times | location =San Mateo, California | page =5 | date =January 11, 1950 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1749635/bahai_observance_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =World Service slated here by Baha'is of area | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =5 | date =January 11, 1950 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/281553/bahai_observance_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Baha'i symposium at armory Sunday marks World Religion Day | newspaper =Hamburg Sun and Erie County Independent | location =Hamburg, New York | page =3 | date =January 18, 1951 | url =http://www.fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2023/Hamburg%20NY%20Sun/Hamburg%20NY%20Sun%201950-1952%20Grayscale/Hamburg%20NY%20Sun%201950-1952%20Grayscale%20-%200337.pdf | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Baha'is observe World Religion Day at meeting | newspaper =Jamestown Post-Journal | location =Jamestown, New York | page =9 | date =January 22, 1951 | url =http://www.fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2023/Jamestown%20NY%20Post%20Journal/Jamestown%20NY%20Post%20Journal%201951/Jamestown%20NY%20Post%20Journal%201951%20-%200519.pdf | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Area Baha'is note World Religion Day | newspaper =The Portsmouth Herald | location =Portsmouth, New Hampshire | page =2 | date =January 23, 1951 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1753904/bahai_observance_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =World Religion Day sponsored by Baha'is | newspaper =The Sun and the Erie County Independent | location =Hamburg, New York | page =2 | date =January 17, 1952 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1754055/world_religion_day_program/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Baha'is schedule religious forum | newspaper =The Charleston Daily Mail | location =Charleston, West Virginia | page =36 | date =January 17, 1952 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1754041/bahai_observance_of_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =World Religion Day sponsored by Baha'is | newspaper =Hamburg Sun and Erie County Independent | location =Hamburg, New York | page =2 | date =January 17, 1952 | url =http://www.fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2023/Hamburg%20NY%20Sun/Hamburg%20NY%20Sun%201950-1952%20Grayscale/Hamburg%20NY%20Sun%201950-1952%20Grayscale%20-%201296.pdf | accessdate = February 14, 2015}} * {{cite news | title =Religious group plans symposium Sunday night | newspaper =Fairbanks Daily News-Miner | location =Fairbanks, Alaska | page =5 | date =January 14, 1955 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1754435/bahais_observe_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Mrs White hostess at religious meet | newspaper =Arizona Daily Sun | location =Flagstaff, Arizona | page =5 | date =January 15, 1959 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1755470/bahais_observe_world_religion_day_with/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Unitarians, baha'is to join in World Religion Day observance | newspaper =The San Bernardino County Sun | location =San Bernardino, California | page =8 | date =January 17, 1959 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1755638/bahais_observe_world_religion_day_with/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Baha'is to observe World Religion Day | newspaper =Pasadena Independent | location =Pasadena, California | page =5 | date =January 17, 1959 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1755906/bahais_observe_world_religion_day/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Baha'is hold series on religions | newspaper =Tucson Daily Citizen | location =Tucson, Arizona | page =11 | date =January 12, 1963 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1756947/bahais_observe_world_religion_day_with/ | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Sunday – World Religion Day observance | newspaper =The Geneva Times | location =Geneva, New York | page =3 | date =January 18, 1968 | url =http://www.fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2011/Geneva%20NY%20Daily%20Times/Geneva%20NY%20Daily%20Times%201968%20Jan-Feb%201968%20Grayscale/Geneva%20NY%20Daily%20Times%201968%20Jan-Feb%201968%20Grayscale%20-%200278.pdf | accessdate = February 14, 2015}} * {{cite news | title =Discuss World's Faiths – Baha'i sponsors religion symposium | newspaper =The Geneva Times | location =Geneva, New York | page =2 | date =January 24, 1968 | url =http://www.fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2011/Geneva%20NY%20Daily%20Times/Geneva%20NY%20Daily%20Times%201968%20Jan-Feb%201968%20Grayscale/Geneva%20NY%20Daily%20Times%201968%20Jan-Feb%201968%20Grayscale%20-%200365.pdf | accessdate =February 14, 2015 }} After years of activity since 2000{{cite AV media | title =A Sacred Life: Beliefs in Action, World Religion Day, 2014 | medium =television | publisher =CTV News | location =Ottawa, Canada | date =January 19, 2014 | url = https://www.youtube.com/v/NnDcAQh1rDI?autoplay=1&rel=0&enablejsapi=1&playerapiid=ytplayer}}{{rp|1:02min}} in 2011 Ottawa city government hosted an event that was video taped.{{cite AV media | people =religions | title =World Religion Day 2011 at Ottawa City Hall | medium =video | publisher =Bahá'ís of Ottawa | location =Ottawa, Canada | date =January 16, 2011 | url =https://www.youtube.com/v/PEODgKwwC-I?autoplay=1&rel=0&enablejsapi=1&playerapiid=ytplayer }} It was subsequently noted in 2014 on [[CTV Television Network]].{{cite AV media | title =A Sacred Life: Beliefs in Action, World Religion Day, 2014 | medium =television | publisher =CT Morning Live | location =Ottawa, Canada | date =January 17, 2014 | url = https://www.youtube.com/v/kIDGBHLKGhw?autoplay=1&rel=0&enablejsapi=1&playerapiid=ytplayer}} Since 2013 participants have gathered at a virtual presentation in [[Second Life]]{{cite AV media | title =2015 World Religion Day in Second Life | medium =video | publisher =Programa de Paz | location =Second Life, UUTopia | date =January 18, 2015 | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CkhmbznJSWk-I?autoplay=1&rel=0&enablejsapi=1&playerapiid=ytplayer}}{{rp|1:44min}} at the UUtopia Center for an observance.{{cite web | title =2014-01-23 LG Minutes | publisher =First UU Congregation of Second Life | date =January 23, 2014 | url =http://www.fuucsl.org/wp/?p=173 | accessdate = February 14, 2015}} The 2014 observance had screenshots taken.{{cite web | author = pcnewton | title =World Religion Day 2014 in SL | published = | date =January 19, 2014 | url =https://www.flickr.com/photos/28493913@N03/sets/72157639972100453/ | accessdate = February 14, 2015 }} The 2015 event{{cite web | title =2014-12-11 LG Minutes | publisher =First UU Congregation of Second Life | date =December 11, 2014 | url =http://www.fuucsl.org/wp/?p=220#more-220 | accessdate = February 14, 2015 }} of talks of a panel of speakers was recorded. In 2013 the [[Parliament of Religions]] noted it.{{cite web | title =Baha’i World Religion Day January 20 start golden rule conversations | work =The Parliament Blog | publisher =Council for a Parliament of the Word's Religions | date =January 17, 2013 | url =http://www.parliamentofreligions.org/news/index.php/2013/01/bahai-world-religion-day-january-20-start-golden-rule-conversations/ | accessdate = February 14, 2015 }} The [[Oxford University Press]]' blog noted it in 2015.{{cite web | author = Alex Guyver | title =World Religion Day 2015 | work =Oxford University Press's Academic Insights for the Thinking World | publisher =Oxford University Press | date =January 18, 2015 | url =http://blog.oup.com/2015/01/world-religion-day/ | accessdate = February 14, 2015}} ==See also== * [[World Interfaith Harmony Week]] ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{cite book | author-last = Buck | author-first = Christopher | editor-last = Beverley | editor-first =James A. | editor2-last = Jones | editor2-first =Constance A. | title =Religious Celebrations: An Encyclopedia of Holidays, Festivals, Solemn Observances, and Spiritual Commemorations | publisher = ABC-CLIO | volume =1 | edition = illustrated | date =September 13, 2011 | pages =936–939 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=KDU30Ae4S4cC | chapter =World Religion Day (January) | chapterurl =http://bahai-library.com/buck_celebrations_world_day | isbn = 978-1-59884-205-0 | ref = harv }} [[Category:Sunday observances]] [[Category:January observances]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith and other religions]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1949]] [[Category:Holidays and observances by scheduling (nth weekday of the month)]] [[Category:1949 establishments in the United States]]

{{short description|20th and 21st-century American singer and minister of the United Church of Christ}} {{Infobox Christian leader | type = Bishop | name = Yvette Flunder | title = | image = Yvette Flunder at 2011 SF Pride - 1.jpg | caption = Flunder singing at 2011 [[San Francisco Pride]] | church = [[United Church of Christ]] | archdiocese = | diocese = | see = | term = | predecessor = | successor = <!-- Orders --> | ordination = | ordained_by = Walter Hawkins | consecration = | consecrated_by = | rank = <!-- Personal details --> | birth_date = {{birth_date and age|1955|7|29}} | birth_place = [[San Francisco, California]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = |occupation = |spouse = Shirley Miller |children = | previous_post = }}
'''Yvette A. Flunder''' (born July 29, 1955) is an American singer and senior pastor of the City of Refuge [[United Church of Christ]] in [[Oakland, California]] and Presiding Bishop of The Fellowship of Affirming Ministries.
Flunder was born in [[San Francisco, California]] and raised in the [[Church of God in Christ]].<ref name="Childers">{{cite book|last=Flunder|first=Yvette|chapter=Yvette Flunder|editor-last=Childers|editor-first=Jana|title=Birthing the Sermon: Women Preachers on the Creative Process|publisher=[[Chalice Press]]|year=2001|pages=69–70}}</ref> In 1984 she began singing and recording with [[Walter Hawkins]] and the Love Center Choir,<ref name=lgbtran>{{cite interview |last=Flunder |first=Yvette |subject-link=Yvette Flunder |interviewer=Monique Moultrie |title=Oral History Interview: Yvette Flunder |url=https://www.lgbtran.org/Exhibits/OralHistory/Flunder/YFlunder.pdf |publisher= |location= |date=February 28, 2011 |work=LGBTRAN: The Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Religious Archives Network|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref> where she was the lead singer.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Koenig|first1=Harold|last2=Weatherford|first2=Carole|last3=Weatherford|first3=Ronald|title=Somebody's Knocking at Your Door: AIDS and the African-American Church|publisher=Routledge|page=33|year=2013}}</ref> She was later ordained by Hawkins.<ref name=working>{{cite web |url=https://www.workingpreacher.org/profile/default.aspx?uid=2_flunder_yvette|title= Yvette Flunder — Profile|website=www.workingpreacher.org |publisher=Working Preacher |access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
In 1986, Flunder was moved to begin working with and ministering to people with HIV/AIDS in response to the [[HIV/AIDS in the United States|epidemic of the 1980s]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Wuthnow|first=Robert|title=All in Sync: How Music and Art Are Revitalizing American Religion|publisher=University of California Press|page=173|year=2003}}</ref> She founded several not-for-profit enterprises in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], providing services for people affected by HIV: Hazard-Ashley House, Walker House and Restoration House, through the Ark of Refuge, Inc., which later became the Y. A. Flunder Foundation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sksm.edu/people/rev-dr-yvette-a-flunder/|title= Rev. Dr. Yvette A. Flunder|website=www.sksm.edu |publisher=Starr King School for the Ministry |access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref> In 1991, she founded the City of Refuge under the [[United Church of Christ]], "in order to unite a gospel ministry with a social ministry".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://d3n8a8pro7vhmx.cloudfront.net/unitedchurchofchrist/legacy_url/17290/ncli-2007-program-book.pdf?1418443709|title= New Church Planter Leadership Institute Program Book| date=2007|publisher=[[United Church of Christ]] |access-date=February 6, 2018}}[http://www.ucc.org/newchurch/pdfs/ncli-2007-program-book.pdf NCLI 2007 Program Book - United Church of Christ]</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.radicallyinclusive.com/our-presiding-bishop|title= Our Presiding Bishop|website=www.radicallyinclusive.com |last=Brown|first=Vanessa|publisher=The Fellowship of Affirming Ministries |access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref> She describes the City of Refuge UCC as an effort to "create a spiritual community that will embrace our collective cultures, faith paths, gender expressions, and sexual/affectional orientations while simultaneously freeing us from oppressive theologies that subjugate women, denigrate the LGBT community, and disconnect us from justice issues locally and globally".<ref>{{cite book|last=Flunder|first=Yvette|chapter=Healing Oppression Sickness|title=Queer Christianities: Lived Religion in Transgressive Forms|editor-last1=Talvacchia|editor-first1=Kathleen|editor-last2=Larrimore|editor-first2=Mark|editor-last3=Pettinger|editor-first3=Michael|publisher=NYU Press|pages=116–117|year=2014}}</ref>
Flunder earned a Certificate of Ministry Studies and a Master of Arts in 1997 from the [[Pacific School of Religion]], before earning her Doctor of Ministry degree from the [[San Francisco Theological Seminary]] in 2001.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://sfts.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Chimes-2014_3.pdf|title=Alumni Updates|work= CHIMES: San Francisco Theological Seminary Newsletter|page=27|volume=60|issue=2|date=Winter 2015|editor-last=Howard|editor-first=Rachel|publisher=[[San Francisco Theological Seminary]]|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref> In 2000 she founded the Fellowship of Affirming Ministries, a trans-denominational coalition of Christian churches who "desire to celebrate and proclaim the radically inclusive love of Jesus Christ",<ref name=essence>{{cite web |url=http://www.radicallyinclusive.com/content.cfm?id=200|title= The Essence of The Fellowship|website=www.radicallyinclusive.com |publisher=The Fellowship of Affirming Ministries |access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref> and was appointed its Presiding Bishop in 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cityofrefugeucc.org/uploads/8/1/7/2/81728266/yflunderupdated_bio_2015.pdf|date=2015|title= About Bishop Flunder|website=www.cityofrefugeucc.org |publisher=City of Refuge United Church of Christ |access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
Flunder identifies as a [[womanist]] and a reconciling [[liberation theology|liberation theologian]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Flunder|first=Yvette|chapter=Yvette Flunder|editor-last=Childers|editor-first=Jana|title=Birthing the Sermon: Women Preachers on the Creative Process|publisher=[[Chalice Press]]|year=2001|page=68}}</ref> In 2005 she authored a book, ''Where the Edge Gathers: Building a Community of Radical Inclusion''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Flunder|first=Yvette|title=Where the Edge Gathers: Building a Community of Radical Inclusion|publisher=Pilgrim Press|year=2005}}</ref> [[Carlton Pearson]] cites her among the first religious leaders to embrace and encourage him after he was declared a [[heretic]] due to coming out in support of [[universal reconciliation]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Pearson|first=Carlton|title=The Gospel of Inclusion: Reaching Beyond Religious Fundamentalism to the True Love of God|publisher=Simon and Schuster|year=2009|pages=75–76}}</ref>
In 2013 she was named as a Distinguished Alumna of the Pacific School of Religion.<ref name=essence /> On December 1, 2014, Flunder was a keynote speaker in the [[White House]] for [[World AIDS Day]], where she described the harmful effects of stigma and [[homophobia]] on those living with HIV and on AIDS education in general.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2014/12/11/white-house-observes-world-aids-day-2014|date=December 11, 2014|last=Brooks|first=Douglas|title= The White House Observes World AIDS Day 2014|website=obamawhitehouse.archives.gov |access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref> The following year she was a guest speaker at the [[American Baptist College]]'s Garnett-Nabrit Lecture Series.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abcnash.edu/events/2015/03/15/2015-garrnett-nabrit-lecture-series.1261804|date=March 15, 2015|title= 2015 Garnett-Nabritt Lecture Series|website=www.abcnash.edu |publisher=American Baptist College| access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
Since 2015 Flunder has been a member of the board of trustees of the [[Starr King School for the Ministry]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sksm.edu/2015/03/16/welcome-to-rev-dr-yvette-flunder-2/|date=March 16, 2015|title= Welcome to Rev. Dr. Yvette Flunder|website=www.sksm.edu |publisher=[[Starr King School for the Ministry]]| access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref> and also served as a member of the [[Presidential Advisory Council on HIV/AIDS]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224143535/https://www.aids.gov/federal-resources/pacha/members/|title= Members & Staff |date=January 20, 2017|publisher=[[Presidential Advisory Council on HIV/AIDS]]| access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
Flunder's spouse is Shirley Miller, the cousin of Walter Hawkins; they have been committed partners since the mid-1980s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.onetruestoryatatime.com/our-stories/category/bishop-yvette-flunder-mother-miller|title= Our Love That Has Lasted 30 Years — Bishop Yvette Flunder and Mother Shirley Miller |date=September 22, 2014|publisher=One True Story at a Time| access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
==Portrayals on film and television==
Flunder was portrayed by actress [[Phylicia Rashad]] for the final 3-part episode as part of the [[Dustin Lance Black]] mini-series ''[[When We Rise]]'' on March 3, 2017 on the major television network [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. The Bishop's role in the show highlights the compassion of the church, the commitment of its leadership and the loving home the church provides to minister in the tough, primarily African-American community in San Francisco.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ew.com/recap/when-we-rise-series-finale/2/|last=Ferguson|first=Latoya|title= When We Rise finale recap: 'Part IV' |date=March 3, 2017|website=ew.com| publisher=One True Story at a Time| access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
Flunder was also depicted by Joni Bovill<ref>{{cite news |last=Bovill |first=Kirk |url=https://www.pr.com/press-release/699773 |title=Joni Bovill Joins Netflix Film "Come Sunday" with Chiwetel Ejiofor |work=pr.com |date=December 25, 2016 |accessdate=2018-04-03 }}</ref> in the [[Joshua Marston]] drama film ''[[Come Sunday (film)|Come Sunday]]'', which premiered at the [[2018 Sundance Film Festival]] and was released on [[Netflix]] in April 2018.<ref>{{cite news |last=Debruge |first=Peter |url=https://variety.com/2018/film/reviews/come-sunday-review-1202671818/ |title=Sundance Film Review: ‘Come Sunday’ |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=January 22, 2018 |accessdate=2018-04-03 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/29/movies/a-sneak-preview-of-2018-netflix-films-and-a-canine-secret-weapon.html|title=A Sneak Preview of 2018 Netflix Films and a Canine Secret Weapon|website=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=The New York Times Company|first=Glen|last=Kenny|date=December 29, 2017|accessdate=2018-06-04}}</ref>
